description:
Fast service, good vegetarian options, and really yummy food.

Everything seems priced reasonably too, which is nice.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
I had heard about Lers Ros quite a few times before, and although this location has a slightly lower rating than the others, I like the Mission area so I decided to take my family here for a birthday dinner. Although we had a reservation for the later evening, the restaurant remained crowded until past 9PM. I appreciated the ambiance, but I felt like it was a little too loud inside (though that may have just been the result of a large group seated near us). 

We were pleased to find that there was a separate selection of vegetarian options, and I was also impressed to see the general variety offered; the menu had everything from classics like chicken and pork to rarities like alligator and rabbit. For appetizers, we ordered the egg rolls and the house green salad. The former was average, but I really enjoyed the salad; it had fried tofu and a slightly nutty dressing that were both great additions to the salad. Then, we ordered the spicy tofu, pad kee mow, and yellow curry (since the red and green curries both had fish sauce, which is not vegetarian). The spicy tofu was soft but could have been more flavorful -- didn't seem like it had been marinated. I liked the pad kee mow as well, but I wasn't a big fan of the yellow curry because of its slightly sweet aftertaste. 

Pros: very fast service, fairly large quantities (especially of white rice)
Cons: loud restaurant, slightly expensive, food of average quality 

Would visit again if I was in the area, but would not go out of my way to revisit.
author: Kamu P.

description:
This review is based on the customer service and the food. They served my partner the entree first, then came the bottle of wine and then served me the wrong plate. (How did they get a plate finished before we got our wine bottle corked?) I ordered the tilapia special and it had all the bones and eyeballs attached (I specifically searched the menu to find something boneless). By the time I got my entree the other dish was completed. 
Great flavor, much miscommunication, I explained the situation and they remedied the situation. 
They also advertised a bottle of wine from 2015 but served us a 2017. 
Update your menu!!
author: Michael B.

description:
Hipster prices ($16) for an average plate of barbecue chicken. Brown rice an extra $3.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I haven't been to a Lers Ros Thai in over five years and never to this Mission location. I liked it, but there were people who were falling over themselves over it. The exceedingly boring Andrew Zimmern was raving about it on one of his food travel shows. It was definitely better than most by-the-numbers Thai spots, and I remember clearly how well they prepared pork belly in a couple of their winning dishes. Well, I found myself on 16th Street looking for lunch but not exactly sure what. When I saw the signage for Lers Ros Thai, I knew it would probably be good if memory served me correctly, but it wasn't the culinary nirvana that I was hoping for.

The magic was discernibly missing from my experience. First things first, I entered waiting for someone to serve me. After about five minutes, a cheerful server led me to the table next to the front window since the lunch rush had already passed through. After another couple of minutes, a more senior server interrogated me about why I was at such a prime table to which I quivered and told her that her colleague led me there. She left without apology and let the first server take care of me. Not a great start. The clear deal to get was the $12.95 Combo Lunch Special where you have your choice from a list of sixteen items.

I decided on the Kai Yang (BBQ Marinated Chicken) and the Green Curry. A house salad came with the special, and it was a refreshing start (photo: http://bit.ly/2MYhJs4). My main plate arrived soon after, and I saw the Kai Yang, but I didn't get the Green Curry. I got the Pad Pak Ruam Mit, a small bowl filled with stir-fried mixed vegetables and tofu in bean sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2wjjHtA). I pointed out the lapse to the server who appeared fearful to take the plate back to the kitchen. I relented and told her I'll keep the Pad Pak, which was fine if somewhat bland. So all in all, the price was good as were the flavors and the portions. But man, where was the love...and respect?

FOOD - 3.5 stars...good if somewhat bland flavors but it would have been better if they got my order right
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...it was a nice table but it would have been nice to feel like I deserved it
SERVICE - 2 stars...a series of miscommunications 
TOTAL - 3 stars...yep, definitely not my previously fond memory of Lers Ros Thai

RELATED - Looking for other dining options in the Mission? Here's a list of the places I've tried and reviewed: http://bit.ly/2PJFItz
author: Ed U.

description: Closed by City and County of San Francisco Dept of Public Health until further notice.
author: Pegs C.

description:
Solid food option if you are in the mission area. I have never had to wait to be seated, unlike some other local places, and the food comes relatively fast. Their coconut curry is one of my favorites to have alongside their fried chicken over rice. 
While dining it has felt a little chaotic due to a lot of food service pickups (like postmates) running back and forth from the front of the restaurant to the back. Other then that, all my experiences here have been fine.
author: Alejandra A.

description:
As usual, Our evening began wondering what we wanted to eat. There was the added pressure of my mom being in town and we wanted her to explore something new. After some deliberation we landed on thai, and of course lers ros was our first choice. It is centrally located in the lively mission a few blocks away from the hustle and bustle of valencia street. 

We started off with a chicken soup. It really prepped us for the main course as it was very warm and creamy. It had different notes that were very reminiscent of ginger. It was both soulful and refreshing. Our selected protein was chicken. 

We then proceeded to our entrees. It was my mom's first time, so she made a safe choice and picked the chicken in peanut sauce. I picked the venison. And the other party picked the alligator. The venison and the alligator had the same base of condiments with the exception that the venison had coconut milk. This made it simmer a little better and the gamy taste of venison was muted with tropical notes. What I didn't like was that both the alligator and the venison were a little chewy/rubbery, so I wouldn't order that plate again. However,  the flavors were on point. The chicken was cooked to perfection. 

I would described the ambience of this place as rustic luxe. It feels very high class and like a lounge. However, the dark tones, wood accents, and exceptional staff make it warm and welcoming. If you are ever in the mood for thai, consider lers ors! Next time I come i will order the green curry, it sounded like it would be my favorite thing. Let me know if you order it first.
author: Emmanuel T.

description: I'm a fan! I usually don't come to this location, but the last few times I've been here, my experience has been great! I usually go with a group and we all love food so much and decide to share everything. Can't go wrong with their curry puffs, yellow curry, pad thai, and fried rice! It is enough to share with two very hungry people or three! The workers are always very sweet and I've never waited too long for a table and my food!
author: Kassie E.

description: Good food and ambiance. Highly recommended! I am very picky about my Thai food and they nailed it! Flavor is on point! I look forward to more visits!
author: Farah S.

description: We didn't know that this restaurant had multiple locations so be careful when you are organizing with other people and be specific with the location. The restaurant is modern, but casual. There are a lot of menu options so it took us awhile to decide what to get. You will find the Thai staples like Pad Thai and Pad See Ew, but you will also find many other Thai dishes that you likely haven't heard of. I liked everything we tried. It was inexpensive and it came out quickly. Would be happy to go back.
author: Vivian C.

description:
I love this place. Great food, quick service. 
Cant spell the menu names right, but I always get the Pad Ke Mow with chicken (this is great if you like salty, not sweet dishes) and the coconut soup with prawns (love the oyster mushrooms in the soup).
author: Zita M.

description:
Price: 5/5
The prices here are phenomenal. There's also free refills on tea! When I'm eating Asian food, that's pretty important to me. None of that by-the-cup nonsense.

Food/service: 4/5
In addition to great prices, the food here is pretty tasty! Unfortunately I can't speak to the authenticity but I can speak for my tastebuds. Some of the dishes I had were a bit too sweet and too salty, and at times we had to flag the waitress down even though it wasn't very crowded, but all in all I'm happy with this restaurant! Nothing is better than having a hot noodle soup on a brisk San Francisco evening, and the ambiance and kind service make Lers Ros a classy yet homey place to be in the Mission.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Since this is the 3rd version of Lers Ros Thai that I've been to in San Francisco, I feel confident in saying that the consistency in their food quality is quite dependable.  This restaurant is located in the Mission, and there is a stylish yet minimalist vibe to the place.  I went there for a weekday lunch, and it looked like I entered before a busy crowd could develop.  My waiter was friendly and quickly took my order.

They have an extensive lunch menu that includes rice plates, and I decided to try their Kha Na Moo Krob.  The pork was had a perfectly crispy exterior while maintaining the tender and juicy pork interior, and I enjoyed the crunch of the sautéed Chinese broccoli.  The dish came with a house salad that had a tangy dressing; it was light but ultimately, the salad did not leave much of an impact during the meal.  Overall, my visit reminded me of how much Lers Ros serves delectable Thai food in San Francisco, and I would happily visit any of their three locations again.
author: Keith H.

description: A lovely place in the Mission ( within walking distance of Bart). Long tables can accommodate groups of 8-10 people...but there are smaller tables for 2-4 people.  The spicy pumpkin shrimp curry served with rice was really exceptional...accompanied by a Singha beer, made for a satisfying lunch.  The decor was warm and welcoming.
author: Mabe S.

description:
I made Mothers day reservations online at Leers Ros Thai on 16th St. In the Mission. We've been to the Larkin location several times but since 16th St. was closer we gave them a try. Reservations were easy online a week before for a 7 pm dinner. The tables are still small but less cramped then the Larkin restaurant. Our server Cherry was very informative in our questions about the dishes and provided excellent service through out the night. We ordered the following:

Starters 
Grilled pork shoulder 5 stars tender and flavorful
Papaya salad with salted duck eggs 4 stars 
Coconut Chicken soup 3 stars very basic

Mains
Lers Ros Sea Bass 5 stars best dish of the night sweet and sour
Pork belly 5 stars my personal favorite 
Shrimp paste fried rice 4 stars lots of shrimp in the rice
Black pepper beef 2 stars worst dish of the night sliced grilled beef in a super salty black sauce " not recommended ".

Street parking in the Mission is a hard so we took a Lyft.  Service and food was good. The only gripe is the pace of the meal. With the tiny tables all the dishes from the starters to the mains all come at once and its a rush to eat and keep clearing dishes to make room for the ones on the way. $136 before tip.
author: George F.

description: Great food! I went with my family and we loved it. The dishes are pretty big. We were 5 people and it was a lot of food. We got 5 different rice plates (fried chicken, beef, shrimp and others) and everything was good!
author: Leila C.

description:
I had the pork shoulder app, the khao kha moo, and the kiddo had shrimp pad see ew. We also ordered sticky rice and mango. I'm used to eating at the Tenderloin location when I used to live a block away. I loved that location and brought everyone there who visited me. They've expanded since I've left the city and when I saw that they had a location close to where I was here for the day I knew I had to visit. 
I was a little wary of the 3 star reviews but everything was still as delicious as I remembered. The sauces are delicious and that pickled mustard green is so good. The kiddo enjoyed his meal. Location is nice, ambiance is nice, service was friendly. Sticky rice in the dessert was a little sloppy though. Wtf. 

I'd be back!
author: Walerz B.

description:
Easily my favorite thai place in the city. 

We ordered pad see ew and durian sticky rice. Pad see ew was amazing. Some pieces of the noodles were slightly burned but it doesn't change the fact that they were delicious. I personally have not had better pad see ew. Many places overcook the noodles and they became soggy. 

Durian sticky rice is a nice variation from mango sticky rice. It's not the most photogenic dessert. A bit too sweet if you have the entire dessert to yourself but it's good for sharing.

Note: this review was written by my SO
author: Tom P.

description:
Everything was fantastic. Great service. Food got to the table quickly. We ordered and it was like magic. I can't believe I pass by this place all the time. The food was seriously top notch.

Next time I go, I'll update this review with useful things to tantalize you. But I wanted to get the 5 stars up here ASAP because, wow. Just wow. Eat here. Make yourself happy.
author: Jason G.

description: I came here a second time regardless of the inaccessibility because the food is delicious. It is a great Thai restaurant. However, the second time I came here, I brought my service animal and have never been treated more rudely in the city of San Francisco. From the moment I came in the door, which has a step to get in, I felt very uncomfortable and as if I was not welcome at all. After being pushed into a hidden corner with zero room, we were only served on one time across our 1.5hr being there and that was to have our order taken. As uncomfortable as I felt, I don't care how good the food is I just don't feel comfortable ever returning, especially as a person with a disability.
author: Jacob R.

description: Meh. I got the kao kah moo, which was a "well stewed pork leg in five spices." Definitely well portioned. I liked that the dish had vegetables (which made me feel a bit healthier), but the dish was heavy on the rice. The pork was very fatty; there wasn't that much actual pork so I didn't feel like I was getting the well stewed pork leg that the menu advertised. It is also a little inconvenient that we had to order rice on the side, even though that is common in some of the more up-scale Thai restaurants. My friends both ended up getting noodle dishes because they didn't want to order the extra rice.
author: Julianna K.

description:
With so many Thai restaurants in the area, there has bound to be a bit of competition.  Came here on a Monday evening around 645pm and there was no wait and a good amount of empty tables. It did get busier about 30 minutes later.  

My friend and I ordered the pad ka prow(crispy pork belly with Thai basil), the barbeque chicken with sweet and sour sauce, and their tom yum noodles which was on their special menu.

Most of the dishes were pretty lack luster.  The noodles were alright. The pad ka prow was doused in sauce and ended up super salty when eating it on its own; it might have been better if you had a bowl of rice to soak up some of the flavor and saltiness.  The crispiness of the pork skin also was lost because of the overdose of sauce which was pretty disheartening too since that is the best part.

 The worst dish we got was the chicken. It came with 2 breast and 2 drumsticks.  The chicken looked visually appealing but was dry and flavorless. The sauce it came with could not save it. It just was not good.

Maybe it was the dishes we ordered, but there wasn't anything impressive about this place. It does seem to be popular so maybe their do the stereotypical thai dishes better?
author: Jacky C.

description:
We live across the street and keep wanting this place to be our go-to neighborhood Thai, but we keep finding that the meat is pretty low quality, almost inedible. On a few separate occasions, the pork and beef were a really poor cut with a lot of fat and tendons. For the price and upscale-ish vibe, it's pretty disappointing. 

However, the Tom Kha Kai (coconut soup with chicken) is delicious. It comes to the table simmering over a flame and has nice oyster mushrooms in it, so we really only come here anymore for this one dish. 

The servers have always been very nice, but they do a kind of group system where one person takes your order, someone else brings the food, and yet another person might check in on you later. It's not necessarily bad, but kind of awkward to not know who's covering our table or who to ask for the check.
author: Lara K.

description:
Really enjoyed the pork shoulder appetizer. Pork was tender and sauce was salty and limey which made it really refreshing. 

I had the dry noodle which they call - dry Tom yum noodle. It was good-- loved the mix of texture from the crunchy pork skin, the ground meat and the fish cake. I could have used more lime, but it worked out because I repurposed some of the pork shoulder sauce.

Hubby got the pepper chicken. We've had it before. It lacked heat today, but was good otherwise.

On a good day, this place is 5*!  But, the inconsistency around the heat in the pepper chicken dish puts it at 4* in my book
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Ordered delivery and disappointed by the quality of food. 

Spicy red curry to the point it was not edible, fish oil smelly pad thai. And, to top it all off - chicken piece in a vegetarian spicy curry. Never again given there are so many better Thai places in the city that taste better & priced better.
author: Mehak K.

description:
located in the mission, this place is slightly more stylish than the other lers ros ive been to. the food is still pretty consistently good though, and service is decent as well, although it is a little pricey.

Pork shoulder appetizer - amazing. must order! tender pork shoulder with great seasoning. absolutely delicious.

Duck curry - This was okay, just regular duck curry.

Five spices duck over rice - this was delicious. will definitely order this again.
author: Christina N.

description:
Gotta say, this is probably one of the better Thai food places I've been to. The prices are also very reasonable given the quality and quantity of food, especially in such a popular area of San Francisco.

I made a reservation on Reserve and was seated right away. The menu itself was a 4 page English transliteration of northern thai food, many of which I've never heard of. The waitress gave us a few suggestions - the pork belly and fried quail. They even had an option for brown rice.

The service was quick and and the food was delicious. The bill came out to be around $60 with tip and tax for 2 people with 2 entrees, 1 appetizer, and 2 glasses of wine. Not bad at all.
author: Daniel D.

description: Excellent Thai food, fun decor and attention to detail! Came here on a Friday night for a friend's birthday dinner. Ordered a bottle of white wine to go with some of our dishes. Had a veggie pad kee mao, which was delicious. Generous size portion. A bit slow on service because we had to flag someone down to take our order. I appreciated their attention to us casually mentioning our friend's bday. At the end of dinner, they surprised our friend and the rest of us w/ candied banana and vanilla ice cream. Solid Thai food!
author: Thomas L.

description:
Ewwww we ordered 5 dishes for takeout to share and only one was edible. We got beef in 2 of our 5 and it was all fat and tendon in both. Chewy and impossible to eat, we had to push it all to the side. I didn't even let my dog eat it. 

The duck curry wasn't any better- oddly smokey and again the meat quality was questionable at best. 

I used to love this local chain but never again. Avoid and try a different place in the Mission.
author: Desiree P.

description: I'm not a huge fan of the pad thai here but I love the Pad See Ew! I also wasn't a big fan of the chicken and rice dish (it was pretty flavorless tbh) but the khao pad ped is delicious if you're a fan of duck! Overall, Lers Ros is a great option if you're looking for good food with no wait and fairly quick service- a godsend in SF!
author: Stephany L.

description:
BOMB ASS PAD THAI. Need I say more ? 



 Ok for real tho. Good music, no lines, fast  service, mellow vibes, away from the Main Street. Only downside: they charge for extra cucumber sauce that came with chicken satay.  Lol see my picture of how small.
author: Carleen C.

description:
3.5 STARS

The roommate wanted curry for dinner. Asked me if I'd rather have Indian or Thai. I picked Thai and we landed on Lers Ros. I liked the food at the Tenderloin location, so we decided to try the Mission location. It was Sunday, March 20th and we ordered delivery through Caviar. Placed the order at 7:26pm and it arrived at 9:05pm. I live in Outer Richmond.

Prices below are what I paid using Caviar. Compared to the online menu on their site, the sides of rice were priced the same. Everything else was priced higher by only $0.05 per item.

*Tom Yum - Hot and Sour Soup: Traditional spicy and sour soup ($12), Shrimp (+$3)
*Papaya Salad: Shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, and lime based salad dressing, Extra spicy ($10), with Raw crab (+$1)
*Larb Pork, Chicken, Duck or Tofu: Chili powder and lime based salad dressing ($9), Duck: A chunk of roasted duck mixed with rice powder (+$3)
*Green Curry: Medium spicy green curry with Thai eggplant, bamboo shoot, red bell peppers, and kaffir lime leaves, Does not include rice, Extra spicy ($12), Chicken (+$1)
*Pad Thai: Traditional Thai style pan-fried rice noodles, No crushed peanut ($10), add Chicken (+$1)
*Lek Tom Yum Haeng - Dry Tom Yum Noodle: Steamed skinny rice noodle with ground pork, slice fish cake, plain crispy pork belly serving with an idea of dry tom yum noodle ($11)
*Brown Rice ($2)
*Jasmine White Rice ($1.50)

I just ordered the papaya salad and duck larb. The salad was good, but it could have been a bit spicier, saltier and fisher. I love papaya salad with a strong contrast in flavors. It was actually better the next day because the flavors developed. I enjoyed the larb, but I found it too salty. I added a bunch of sambal to try and balance it out. The roommate knows I love a nice spicy green curry so he ordered that. It was creamy with lots of chicken, bamboo, mushrooms, etc. For being extra spicy, I wanted more of a kick, but it had great flavors. Went well with my brown rice. The soup had coconut milk in it which made it a little more mellow than I'd like. It cut into the heat which I didn't necessarily want. The pad thai looked bland, but surprisingly had great flavor. The noodles also had a nice chew. I didn't try dry tom yum, but the roommate seemed to enjoy it.

I was tempted to order the fish dish I love, but I refrained as it's huge. I also adore their pork shoulder. Even though I remember the dishes at the TL location being bolder in flavors, this Lers Ros location still served some solid dishes.
author: Elena N.

description:
I still like going to Lers Ros for Thai food. I know people will say it may be over hyped, but just think this place started off in tenderloin and has two other locations. This being one of them. It's a great Thai place to satisfy your craving. Everything is authentic about the food. 

I called as I was on the way to the mission location and I was shock that there was no wait. I usually go to the Larkin location where I am usually waiting 45 minutes to eat. This location is smaller and more modern looking. Great from groups of 2-6 I can't say a large party would do well here. 

Menu is the same and so is the price. So I will always suggest their grilled pork shoulder, red curry, and pad kee mao. You can't go wrong with it.
author: Jackie N.

description:
First time here! Wasn't disappointed with the food or menu options.

Took an Uber because parking would have been awful! We made reservations for our party of 8 and were seated within 5 mins of our arrival - yay!

Menu options were plenty! They have some regular Thai dishes here (curry, pad thai, pad see ew, etc.), but they've also got some really exotic dishes too (frog, rabbit, etc.). We decided to save the exotic stuff for another time.

I ordered the Pad See Ew with chicken. Basically my standard for any thai place so I can compare them on an even playing field... and it was delicious! Flavor was spot on and the dish didn't look like much when it was served, but I was full by the time I cleaned up the plate!
author: Wing L.

description:
Ler Ros - this is where you go for Thai food on "date night."

In addition to the traditional Thai staples of other restaurants (yellow chicken curry, pad thai, pad see yew, etc.), Ler Ros has a selection of more unique dishes that is hard to find anywhere else in San Francisco/Bay Area. Ler Ros also has a good selection of wine and the restaurant is pretty clean (without sacrificing that authentic Thai taste!).

With that being said, Ler Ros prices are higher than most other Thai restaurants so if you try their food, avoid the common dishes and order something you've never tried before.

Enjoy!
author: John L.

description:
TLDR - good spot for fancy Thai food in a trendy atmosphere, but expect to pay more than you would at a more authentic Thai spot

Stopped by with some friends for a super late lunch on a weekend. And by super late, I mean like 3:30pm.. 30 minutes before they closed for the afternoon. Naturally, the place was pretty empty.

The restaurant is really nice. Super trendy decor and ambiance. Don't come expecting authentic Thai food though. This spot is definitely more of that fancy Thai where you're paying more than you should for Thai food even though the food isn't as authentic. The food was still delicious and tasty though.

-GARLIC QUAIL ($10.95) - 4.5/5
Crispy and tender! A little fatty and greasy but yummy

-NUER PAD PRIK ($13.95) - 4.5/5
[beef stir-fried w/ chili paste, bell peppers, bamboo shoot, basil]
MMM lots of flavor (coconutty) and the chili packed a good kick! The beef was really tender too

-PAD SEE EW ($10.95) - 3.5/5
Flavor was pretty good/lightly sweet, but the noodles were on the greasy side. We got ours with chicken, which was cooked well. Overall, solid but didn't really stand out in comparison to pad see ew at other Thai restaurants

-KANG KAREE ($12.95) - 3/5
[yellow curry w/ potatoes, yellow onion]
Meh. $13 for just potatoes and onions and no meat? And for a dish that had no meat, the portion size was still really small.. Tasted like pretty standard yellow curry. I'd pass in the future
author: Jessie L.

description: This place is great!  Love their pad Thai and green curry!  Super friendly service!    Love it
author: Jerry W.

description:
I was surprised there were a good number of empty tables when we got there at 8:30pm on a Saturday.  We had a bunch of drinks at ABV across the street and needed some carbs...

We went with some of our go-to dishes:
1. Neur yang: grilled beef - really intense flavor with a nice char (without being dry.) The dressing on the side is really good, too 
2. Pad Thai with chicken: this hit the spot. It's a bit on the sweet side, though 
3. Tom yum soup: with shrimp; we asked for it without coconut milk. This was super fragrant, served in a heated pot, very umami (I want to salivate thinking about the flavor)
4. Shrimp paste fried rice: nice texture on the rice  

Service was friendly, and food came out quickly.  It's more expensive than some other Thai places, but Lers Ros is still one of my favorites for Thai.
author: Marilyn T.

description: Another great place for Phad Thai and currys.  Will come back again. A bit expensive but the food and service are good. The restaurant interior is very contemporary and would make a good date spot.  I've been here twice for dinner and had no problems getting a seat.
author: Richard M.

description:
4 stars is solely for the 'Lek Tom Yum Haeng', a dry noodle dish with pork that was so delicious that I kept eating it even after I was full! I wasn't too fond of the duck in red curry dish as it was a bit too sweet and the curry flavor wasn't too strong. The chicken satay was ok.

It was surprisingly empty for a Friday night.. just a few tables and lots of open seating. I guess Thai food isn't quite on everyone's mind when they think to dine in the Mission District. Service was good, almost too good that you feel slightly uneasy because you know your every move is being watched.. as soon as you finish the last bite of your dish, there's someone there to take the plate away. We were stuffed but didn't stay to chat since our table was quickly cleared out.
author: Ruby C.

description:
I haven't been to the original Tenderloin location, but I had a five-star experience (both for service + food) last night. Not sure why the reviews are so mixed. 

My friend and I declared this some of the best Thai food we've had in a while; she even went to Thailand recently and said the food here was authentic and comparable.

The menu is a bit overwhelming, so we stuck to the daily specials and recommendations from our server. Ended up with the following:
+ Pork shoulder appetizer. So moist and flavorful. That side sauce was great too.
+ Shrimp paste fried rice w/ salted egg. Holy crap was this good. This had a kick to it thanks to the peppers. It was so much food that we couldn't finish and took it home.
+ Lek tom yum haeng (the dry tom yum noodles). The photos made it look small, but it's actually a decent portion...it's just served in a bigass bowl. Definitely a must-order if it's available - it's a really unique, sweet & savory dish.

The servers were all so nice and helpful. They boxed up the leftovers for us and gave us some tips on things to do in Thailand (I'm going next month).
author: Valerie L.

description:
After trying out my fair share of Thai restaurants in the city, I must say that Lers Ros comes out on top and remains my all around favorite! Just like the other locations, the Lers Ros on 16th St has elegant and modern decor, and most importantly, authentic and clean Thai flavors.

I came here for dinner with a group of four and our tastebuds were in for quite a treat! We started our with two appetizers--the grilled pork shoulder, which was perfectly spiced and served with a savory dark sauce that rounded out the flavors perfectly, and the som tum papaya salad with raw crab. The papaya salad was one of the spiciest (and tastiest) I've ever had--it was cooled down by the tomato and green beans, as well as the raw cabbage leaves on the side. The raw crab was also amazing and had the perfect amount of funky flavor to it!

And then came our main courses--we had the Lek Tom Yum Haeng, a rice noodle dish that came in a spicy sauce and was served along pork belly, pork slices, ground pork, and fish cake. Though this dish seems very simple, the combination of flavors is unbelievable, and even the texture of the noodles is worth writing home about! We also had the green curry with chicken, which was perfect in every way--the white meat chicken was amazingly tender, and the vegetables and curry had such great flavor. The curry did not have a muddled taste (as some curries that are overcooked do)--each of the elements were distinct, but they each came together to make a single delicious dish. Third, we had the prawn and asparagus stir-fry; while this was a fairly typical Thai stir-fry and not a particularly creative dish, it was executed absolutely perfectly--the vegetables were all fresh and cooked just the right amount, while the stir-fry sauce was not overpoweringly salty.

The last main course dish we had was the star of the show--the steamed black bass. It was a whole fish served in a hot pot (which was in the shape of a fish!) with a flame underneath to keep it warm. The bass was tender and juicy, but the real stand out element of this dish was the citrusy, lemony broth the fish was cooked in. I don't know what it was about it that paired so well with the fish, but it was absolutely irresistible and definitely my favorite dish of the night. 

Overall, Lers Ros was an absolutely fantastic Thai restaurant with super authentic dishes that were all perfectly executed and had very clean flavors. I will definitely be coming back in the future to sample more of their huge selection!
author: David K.

description:
Good decor but very mediocre food. We ordered the pad prik beef which looked flavorful from pics but the vivid color doesn't actually translate to any good taste. The beef doesn't taste fresh and is hard to swallow. 
The waitress and waiter were very nice although not very effective (i.e. in knowing the menu).
They have wifi here which is great.(although bit slow)
author: Mei T.

description: The Tom Yum soup stood out even though a lot of places make a good one. The papaya salad also had good heat to it which you don't typically see.
author: riz n.

description:
Don't let the tacky interior scare you away (because it did the many times I've walked by, strolling around the Mission), this place is great! I first tried it at the San Francisco Street Food Festival. Khao mun gai is one of the most basic Thai street foods, and it was so good, so nostalgic, that I had to go to the restaurant. 

The place was empty on a Friday night. So empty that the servers were borderline too attentive. This doesn't really mean anything to me, though, because delivery boys were running in and out with take out all night (which sounds like the pretty standard Netflix and chill Friday night to me). 

We tried the Lek Tom Yum Haeng (dry rice noodles with pork and chicken) and the duck red curry. The noodles were weird initially... and then after a few more bites they immediately became one of the top 3 foods I would take to a deserted island. Delicious. Highly recommended.

The duck curry- good. Thai curry is pretty much always good. Not to much to say about this one. 

Chicken satay- also good, pretty standard. Even though the chicken was cut pretty thinly, I felt like it was lacking a little bit of flavor from the marinate. Nothing a little peanut sauce can't fix though.

Next time I'll order take out from here cause the servers and the dumb decorations were just too much for me.
author: Steph D.

description:
Delicious.  
Most like the actual foods we love when in Thailand itself that we've found outside that tropical food paradise.

Chili-basil fried whole fish!  Do it.  You won't regret it.

I am a green papaya salad super fan.  Here, I preferred Som Tom with shrimp to the version with raw crab.  You might feel differently.  The very small crabs were hard to deal with unless one used fingers and got super sticky.  Then, the amount of flavor added didn't seem worth the mess plus effort.  One can eat the soft-ish shells.  I did that  a bit.  Probably increased my calcium that meal.  Talk about crunch!!

Medium spicy hit the spot for us.  We like pretty damn spicy, so, unless you're actually accustomed to the insane levels of heat in Thailand itself, I recommend staying away from "hot".   For others who crave that pain-so-good feeling chili provides, give medium a try with an appetizer and adjust your ordering of main courses as you feel right right.
Note:  If you're palate is up to twice as spice-friendly as the average American, stick with mild.  

Lers Ros' green curry never disappoints.  Neither do other colors of curry, but there's something about that mix of sweet, salt, and spice in this green version that tickles my taste receptors just right.

Vegetable dishes: try them all.   Every single one is full of fantastic flavors.

Note: actual vegans and vegetarians beware fish sauce that is likely hard to avoid.  I'm not sure that you can trust any statements about any dishes lacking this ingredient; perhaps Lers Ros, as a pretty darn sophisticated outfit, does get the needs of those who avoid all fish and other animal products, but you had better take some extra steps to ensure you can order dishes that are truly 100% vegan/vegetarian before coming here and finding disappointment.

Plenty of beer [ none on tap :-(  ] and delicious wines available.

Not a cheap Thai joint -- but you get at least as much as you pay for.  QPR seems far higher here than most places in hipster haven
author: Scott C.

description:
Although everyone says the original Lers Ros Thai in the Tenderloin is the best, I still think the one in the Mission is just as yummy! I love how adventurous and flavorful the food is. It's my guilty pleasure for all the carbs!

The great things about this place is that it is group friendly, accepts reservations, and not at all crowded when we went! Compared to the one in the Tenderloin, there's a guarantee 1-2 hour wait. 

We came here for a group of 8 for my boyfriend's birthday and it definitely was a crowd pleaser. It ended up only about $25 per person and we ordered too much! The pad thai is delicious and so were the curries. A lot of people loved the rabbit too.
author: Janet H.

description: We ordered the red curry and Pad see ew.  The curry had great flavors and everything was going good until we started eating our noodle dish.  Unfortunately, we found a hair in our pad see ew...making it ewwww.
author: Paula N.

description: Super place.  Very reasonable prices and huge portions.  Service was polite and efficient, and food came super quickly.  Good Pad Thai and a nice selection of beer.
author: Helena T.

description:
***This is my first hand experience with this restaurant location. The important point: all three restaurants are guilty of the same mislabeling of food. THE WORKERS AT THE RESTAURANT RECENTLY HAD MY REVIEWS REMOVED BECAUSE THEY WERE THE SAME ACROSS ALL THREE. Well guess what, that's what happened, I called all thee restaurants to see if the Lers Rose menu has a problem with their vegetarian section. *** This is what happened with the Lers Rose Hayes Valley Location: 

Again, a *third* lady confirmed, AFTER I specifically asked about fish sauce and shrimp paste AS WELL, that ALL the dishes on the vegetarian section contain animal products. Some dishes have to be specifically ordered without fish sauce and shrimp paste, and some such as the Pad Thai and all of their curries CANNOT be made without fish sauce and/or shrimp paste.

Let me make something clear: If your restaurant labels a section in the menu as "vegetarian," I expect those dishes to contain NO MEAT. This is FALSE ADVERTISING and extremely misleading for those who want to avoid eating meat.

A mistake on labeling is one thing, but to know that the food contains animal product and blatantly misleading customers into thinking otherwise is NOT OK. 

* AND TO THE WORKERS AT THE RESTAURANT WHO REQUESTED THAT MY REVIEWS BE REMOVED SO YOU CAN HIDE THIS WELL-DESERVED ONE-STAR REVIEW* Stop ratting out to Yelp about my review being consistent across all three of your restaurants, as I did call all three restaurants, and all three gave the same lies. I'M DONE WITH ALL THREE PLACE AND SO SHOULD EVERYONE WHO IS ETHICAL.

Lers Rose, if you try to report me again I will repost you to BBB, any restaurant regulators, media publications, and directly to Yelp.
author: Vegans Eat 2.

description:
I've been coming to Lers Ros for awhile but only recently discovered the Lek Tom Yum Haeng. Most everything is good but it's not one of my favorites!

* LEK TOM YUM HAENG ($9.95) - 5 STARS:
If you like #25 Dry (aka Ha Nam Ninh Crack Noodles) you'll love this Thai version. I think it's a bit strange that they add white granulated sugar, next time I'll ask for that and peanuts on the side. They give you a generous portion of fresh, al dente noodles, but I wish they provided more sauce. 

* PORK BELLY ENTREE ($11.50) - 5 STARS:
Le chon done right with a very spicy, tasty sauce which goes perfect on rice. The Lers Ros in the Mission does not have the rice plate version.

* PAD SEE EW - 2.5 STARS
OK, not the best. A little too sweet for me. 

* NUER PAD PRIK - 3.5 STARS
Thinly sliced beef in a gravy sauce. Not bad

* YUM WOON SEN - 3.5 STARS
Refreshing and served with a side of iceberg lettuce. I think I personally prefer Pad Woon Sen.
author: Jess C.

description: Got the Rad Nah. It's a noodle dish doused in a gravy sauce. Highly satisfying. I noticed that the broccoli was over-seasoned w/ pepper. Each bite packed a nice punch, but a bit too overpowering considering the lighter nature of the gravy.
author: James N.

description:
The plain rice for several persons came 20 minutes before the food.
.
We asked for an item not on the menu, "Duck Fried Rice" and for $22.95 they made this special request. Not too oily, nor dry with some crisp skin and decent portions of meat I think I will ask for this again.
.
 We also enjoyed the Kaeng Weaw Wan Talay/Seafood Green Curry $15.95. The scallops, shrimp and calamari were very tender not at all chewy.  The green curry base although too sweet was pleasantly spiced and had a decent combination bamboo, corn, carrots, eggplant and may be some red bell pepper. 
.
At $15.95 the Ginger Shrimp and the $10.95 Chicken Noodle Soup were nothing to write home about.
.
For $6.50 Lers Ros produced four little Fried Bananas and an Almond Ice Cream for my group to share.
author: Caesar A.

description:
I love Lers Ros in the Tenderloin and was happy that they opened a location near me in the Mission. Even though I shied away from their best dishes that I've already tried, this location didn't disappoint! This one has trendy decor, somewhat homey with a modern twist, and is darkly lit.

RESERVATIONS: Easily made on their website about half a week in advance, for 4 at 7pm on a Saturday.

THE SERVICE: All good, except they took forever to bring our bill (about 45 minutes, and then only because we asked). They were probably just content with letting us sit and talk though.

THE FOOD: See my photos for more details on each dish.

CHEFS SPECIAL:
* Ginger scallops ($18.95) - 3 stars
We ordered this as a shared appetizer but I couldn't believe it was $18 when we got our bill! The scallops weren't that fresh, a little bit rubbery actually. The ginger wasn't so much infused in the flavor or sauce, but there were lots of large pieces of it in the dish.

DAILY SPECIAL:
* Lek Tom Yum Haeng (steamed skinny rice noodle w/ ground pork, slice fish cake, plain crispy pork belly, peanut, with an idea of Dry Tom Yum Noodle. $10.95) - 4 stars
Although all my noodles initially stuck together in a big glob, once I mixed it all up, it was good. The pork belly cubes were HUGE! I wish they had more crisp. All the meat was very tasty.

COCONUT MILK CURRIES:
* Kang Phed Yang (Red curry with roasted duck, bamboo shoots, red bell peppers, tomatoes and chunk pineapples. $14.95) - 4 stars
I tried some of my boyfriend's curry and this was really tasty.
author: Ziyan C.

description: This review is for delivery via Caviar.  The delivery was brought up to my apartment on time, and the food was flavorful and pleasantly spicy.  We had a green curry with tofu, a noodle dish, and the vegetarian spring rolls.  It was definitely enough for two people for dinner, with at least another meal worth of leftovers.
author: Katie E.

description: I've been to the other location a few times, but this was my first time at this location. I ordered the Kao Mun Kai, which is basically like Hainanese chicken rice. Nicely flavored rice, and nicely steamed and moist chicken. One of my favorite dishes to eat in general, and Lers Ros had a nice rendition. I just wish the portion were a little larger =)
author: Cynthia M.

description: This is my favorite Thai place in the city. There food is soo good and they actually make it spicy when you ask! My favorite dish is the red chicken curry! So bomb!
author: Alanna G.

description: Right off the main drag in Valencia. The portions are pretty big and decently priced. I was a little disappointed in my beef pas see ew the flavor just wasn't as good as others I've had. They also had very little meat and mostly noodles.
author: Karim I.

description: Lers Ros Thai is not cheap. Don't go in thinking that way! The restaurant serves superb Thai cuisine. They have a variety of different dishes. I got the lunch combo with prawns, chicken leg, papaya salad, and sticky rice. The first time I came here, I ordered the equivalent of beef and broccoli. Don't go there and order something lame like I did. Go big or go home!
author: Brian L.

description: I would classify Lers Ros as nouveau Thai cuisine. It has all the usual stuff. The pad Thai and pad see eu we ordered were decent and run of the mill. The green curry was the best dish of our meal. It had the right amount of heat and curry spice. We also ordered the whole fried snapper which was very impressive. It was fried well and I almost eat the whole head as it was so crunchy the bones crunched and were like fish crackling.  The deep fried basil leaves was a nice touch. However I wish that they had added some deep fried garlic slices and chili slices. The accompanying sauce was way too sweet and I had to ask for their chilly caddy to balance out the flavor. I liked it that they had a brown rice option.
author: Christopher Q.

description: This is my neighborhood Thai restaurant and I've been coming here for 4+ years. The food is exceptional but the staff is kind of clueless. You have to check your order right away because they'll give you the wrong food or forget to give you rice. I wouldn't say everything on the menu is spectacular but the duck salad and curry options never disappoint. I typically order to go so I don't get to appreciate the ambiance.
author: Joshua G.

description:
The food is average but the reason I'm giving it a one star is because of the poor service.  

There were only two of us dining, so it was awful when our food was bought out separately. 

I was almost done eating when my dining partner's food came out. 

Avoid this place.
author: S M.

description:
Nothing spectacular here.
Had higher expectations for the papaya salad, but was disappointed by its lack of flavor and spiciness. Portions here are smaller than most Thai restaurants I've been to. The curry puffs were pretty good came out super hot. The chicken satay was dry though and the peanut sauce did not rectify it. 

The interior is kinda weird, looks super modern and futuristic.
Service was inconsistent in the way that the servers don't communicate. Like one of the servers asked us if we were ready to order, but we just ordered through another server. Get it togethaa
author: Christine K.

description:
Nice restaurant to sit down with family and friends to have a real conversation. So TVs everywhere, so no distractions. It is fairly quiet with nice ambience music, but just a little dim. The waist read was very nice to let us sit where ever we wanted for our own comfort. 

What I like was not only the modern decor, but also how they have one wall of booth seats that is made of wood. They have pillows and back rests lined up incase you needed cushion, which I thought was smart. Very nice for Annabelle  

All three things we ordered were great! The red curry was super duper spicy, I was shocked. But it was enjoyable! My favorite was pad Thai because it was sweet, versus the pad see ew which was salty. Would come back if I'm ever in the city again.
author: Annabelle G.

description:
This place is wonderful! The dishes are well-made, flavorful, and the menu offers a variety of dishes (even alligator!).  We went here for a large group reservation, and everything came out in a timely manner.  Service was great.  

I highly recommend this restaurant (I feel like it's the new Osha Thai, but better).  Prices are reasonable, Good sized portions.  Tasty dishes.  Hip environment.
author: Tramy V.

description: I always thought this location is a little underrated. Sure, the food may not rise to the level of the Tenderloin original, but it's still a highly pleasant, reasonably priced authentic Thai meal in a cleanly appointed space, in the middle of the Mission. I've never had a bad time eating there.
author: Ken H.

description:
A posh looking thai restaurant in the mission

Everyone realizes how posh this place looks the moment you walk in. The Vibe is really great--good background music, classy decor/furniture/utensils, and good looking waitstaff :)

The food quality was also good as well. The noodles were better than I had expected, especially given that I had originally expected this place to be more looks than substance. The dishes were actually very well made, with a nice broth for the noodles, and the mango dessert was as sweet and savory as it looked.

Overall, a good place to stop by for a classy group of friends.
author: Henry L.

description:
I've come here for lunch on Sunday several times and it doesn't disappoint.  Definitely better to eat family style than to order an individual dish--I mean, really, is there any other way to eat Thai food?  On my last visit, we ordered:

Lek Tom Yum Haeng - the dry tom yum noodles everyone is raving about are seriously on point.  It was definitely the favorite dish of the bunch.  Sweet, sour, savory, nutty, and delicious.  Lots of good Thai flavor and a unique texture.  Highly recommended.

Tom Kha Kai - coconut milk soup with chicken served in a flaming hot pot (literally).  It was nice and soothing on a cold wintry day and full of meat and mushrooms.  Good sized portion for sharing.

Green Curry Chicken - pretty standard but still delicious.  Also had these small Thai eggplants...but they didn't seem quite cooked--a little too raw for my liking.

We also ordered a pork belly appetizer which was delicious.  They do charge for rice though, which is a no-no in my book.  Because, seriously, how else are you going to eat curry without rice?

Service was slow and it was difficult to get the attention of our waitress.  Probably because there was only one waitress for the entire restaurant at lunch time.  But, the food was delicious.
author: Jess Y.

description: Very good and original flavors. Parking is a little difficult but worth the effort.
author: Eric V.

description:
The ambiance was so nice, I wanted to take a picture of the artsy chandeliers and shiny silver chairs, but I'm sure my touristy dSLR habits would embarrass my friends. So let's just leave it at that and move on to the food.

My friend wanted to order the duck noodle soup and they were out! Our table thus got pad kee mow/pad Thai all around. 

I got my go-to, the VEGETARIAN PAD THAI (Pad Thai Pak, $9 stir-fried Thai noodles with tofu, egg, mixed vegetables, bean sprouts and crushed peanuts) and it was as standard as it could get--it tasted exactly like what you imagine Pad Thai to taste like. This would be a good thing in most cases, but in my opinion, the Thai food that stands out the most are those with such a homemade cooking style, they deviate noticeably from the standard (in a good way, of course). This is exactly what Ler Ros fell short of, and as if they had not already gentrified Thai food enough, the food was terribly salty. 

The partial redemption factors include the large portion size and the fact that the prices were reasonable considering the posh ambiance.

Conclusion: Lers Ros and Osha Thai are both upscale Thai places in SF. While Lers Ros has better prices, I think Osha is more unique. I would recommend either going to Osha for classy fusion Thai food (they have actual fusion dishes as well as traditional food in a fusion presentation), or just a real non-Americanized restaurant for good Thai food.
author: Edna C.

description:
Only rating the take out. Upfront, just as good as the tenderloin location (see my previous review on it).

Pad see ew - marvelous. Has that wok flavor that'll keep you coming back for more. Many thai place overrun the dish with soy sauce so it tastes simply like that, not this place. You'll be thankful you tried it.

Pad Thai - great! It is what you would expect from a peanut-infused noodle dish. Not the best, but by no means, certainly not the worst. One of the better ones in the city. 

Pad Kra Prow - basically this is ground chicken stir fried with some basil leaves. Didn't get much basil in ours, and I've discovered that ground chicken is not the best food in terms of consistency and taste. They did their best with this dish but it falls flat. Real flat. Probably the less-desired dish I've had here. 

Thai iced tea - MUST HAVE. As I've said before, not watered-down, so it's very tasty and rich. 

All we have to do now is try the third location!
author: Edward L.

description: The two dishes I had were okay but tasted bland compared to the other locations. Had the Chicken Satay and Larb Gai. Chicken Satay was good but a bit thin and unremarkable, mainly a vehicle for the peanut sauce. Chicken Larb had a good texture and seasoning, mildly spicy in a slightly tangy salty sweet lime sauce. Service was attentive and okay.
author: Truc N.

description: 5 spiced duck over rice was too crazy savory that we didn't save any for leftovers (and I'm not big into duck).  Everything else was delicious too.  Only thing keeping from a 5 star is we had to remind them about our final dish multiple times as different staff members kept thinking we were done and asked to take our plates.
author: Ben T.

description:
When things start getting a little stale in your love life, it's time to pay a visit to:

(A) A Thai restaurant
(B) Good Vibrations
(C) Both

My vote is for (C). Something to fire up your taste buds AND your whoohaa? Winning.

It's a good thing that Lers Ros newest and their location is just 2 blocks from Good Vibrations on Valencia. It's also their poshest location with EDM music playing making it a hip date place: http://bit.ly/1kvNELM. The music wasn't blaring so it was easy to maintain a convo. Reservations are highly recommended.

I rarely crave Thai food but Lers Ros is an exception. The food at their original TL location (their Hayes Valley location sucks) has always been on point with bold, fiery flavor profiles and unique dishes with frog, alligator, boar, that you would never find at generic Thai restaurants like King of Thai and Osha.

There's over 160 things on their menu not including their Chef's Specials Menu with items exclusive to this Mission location. Definitely skip the usual pad thai and pad see ew and go with raved about favs like the duck larb, stir fried pork belly, and/or grilled pork shoulder. They do use MSG but will leave it out upon request which we did.

I always order Keh Moo Yang: Grilled Pork Shoulder ($9.95) when I visit Lers Ros so just had to order it here: http://bit.ly/1lW0yEB. The pork shoulder was rich and tender but lacking in execution compared to their TL location. It was missing a good sear and the slight crispy exterior. If you never tried the original, it would suffice though.

For our entrees, we decided to go with dishes exclusive to their Mission location. The Beef Pad Prik: Stir-fried beef w/ Thai black pepper & onions ($13.95) had really good flavor and peppery kick but the mandingo sized beef slices could barely fit in my mouth: http://bit.ly/NtvM6U (it's hard to tell in the pic but trust me, these slices were not mouth-friendly). We had to share a knife to cut the beef into 3-4 smaller more manageable pieces. Another dish exclusive to this location was the Pad Phed Venison ($21.95) which was also my fav of the night: http://bit.ly/1iGcq8S. The venison was lean and tender and the sauce had an intense depth of flavor from the red curry, chilies and galanga. I loved the addition of coconut milk for a creamy finish. The brown rice really soaked up all that yummy sauce.

Against Mr. NSS wishes, I ordered the Durian dessert w/ sticky coconut rice ($5.50). Even before the dish arrived, I could smell the cringe-inducing, intoxicating scent of durian fill the room and see the stank eyes on our table when it was delivered to us. I usually love this disgustingly delicious custardy fruit but this dessert was just awful: http://bit.ly/1eNARk2. The fragrant coconut sticky rice was fine but the durian was gross because it was served hot. That's like serving cheesecake hot. Who does that?

Service was typical of an Asian restaurant. Some of the waitresses were passive because of the language barrier but are accommodating as long as you get their attention.

One of my biggest gripes were their plates. Not only were they huge, clunky and took up a lot of room on the table, they made the presentation of the food look sloppy. For some of the dishes, the food seemed to be just thrown on top of the plate like in the last 3 seconds of a Chopped round. When you're paying $80 for Thai food for two (pre-tip), presentation should at least be clean. That's just me being nit-picky though. 

Lers Ros' original TL location is still the best but the Mission location at least has the basic fundamental of bold, fiery Thai flavors down unlike their yuppified Hayes Valley location. They just need to work on their execution. Considering we went on their second day of opening, a generous 4 stars in hopes they work out their kinks.

We had every intent of walking over to Good Vibes after dinner. That's until the revolting smell of durian came a knocking on the back door. Opppsie. Definitely stay away from durian when on a date...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Delicious vegetarian options. The prices are a bit high but the service and quality makes it worth it.  I go weekly. Eggplant tofu rocks.
author: Nick S.

description:
I ordered via Caviar.

Ultimately, I was surprised how good the take-out food was from this restaurant!

I ordered Kao Mun Gai which included crispy chicken and garlic rice with sweet sauce. When I received my food, I put the sauce all over my food and it definitely made it taste much better. The chicken and the garlic rice complemented each other in a way that every bite was a mouthful of flavor.

I would love to try more of their dishes here!
author: Aj C.

description: Had a great meal here.  The beef dish has thick juicy cuts of steak - top shelf Thai.
author: Marcus C.

description:
This is one of the best value meals I've eaten in San Francisco. Ordered the Pad See Ew and I couldn't believe how much food came! The portions are generous and the prices are extremely reasonable, especially given the classy-ish interior of the restaurant and the trendy location. I'd share a dish or expect to take home leftovers.

Tip: try to get a table far from the door. It's getting cold in SF and a huge draft enters the restaurant every time the door opens.
author: Neha S.

description:
Sorry but I don't see why this place gets such good reviews.  

I ordered Pad Thai and came out very oily and quite bland.  I had much better Pad Thai in San Francisco. 

Also the service was quite slow even though it was lunch hour and the place wasn't that crowded.  

The service wasn't too friendly either. 

If they get better service and better cooking I might give this place another try. But there are so many Thai restaurants in SF to give a chance first. 

Price was moderate.
author: Christiani C.

description: This place is awesome! Food came out really hot and fast, they sat our table of 9 very quickly after first saying it would be a 45 minute rate which was awesome! Try to pad see yew or the shrimp pad thai. Good for groups with the family style servings although the restaurant is a little bit small and can get crowded!! Awesome experience overall !
author: Jenna E.

description:
Last month I had traveled to Thailand and taken cooking classes, so it became my quest to find thai food in the US that matched the experiences of Bangkok. I live in a small town outside Santa Barbara, CA so it's not so easy to find ingredients without a jaunt to LA. I'd worked through all my green curry paste I made in the cooking class, so that was my craving. 

The environment was friendly, contemporary, and comfortable. We started with a green papaya salad at medium heat. I love spicy food, but I have stomach issues as well. This level of heat was great for me. The flavors were pretty darn good, but I was not a fan of the way the crab meat was still shelled. No worries my friend was happy to eat all that crab. 

I had the green curry. I was pleasantly surprised to see actual thai eggplant being used. The flavors were very reminiscent of my experiences in Thailand. Complex blend of thai chili, cardamon, lemon grass, peppercorn, and thai basil. I think what was missing was the other thai eggplant that looks like a pea. I was having trouble placing that element in the taste. However, it was a magnificent green curry. My friend had a ginger chicken, which was good but not a flavor I tasted while in Thailand. 

We opted to not have dessert here since they only served wine and we were hankering for a gin and tonic. I'd go back anytime I am in SF and know it's be a good experience.
author: Micheal S.

description:
Food is good. A bit noisy.
The problem is they know how to take a reservation but they don't know how to hold it. And that is the most important part of the reservation - the holding.
author: Patricia K.

description:
Very decent Thai food in a causal setting. The tables were too close to each other to the point of being awkward. 
I ordered the fried tofu and fish paste fried rice with shrimp. My friend ordered the ginger quail and garlic chicken. The food was decent without being amazing.
author: Sadique A.

description:
3.5 stars.  Rounding up because I've previously had an excellent fried fish dish at the TL location so I know what Lers Ros is capable of...

First, I must say that the Duck Larb is excellent.  Based on looks, I definitely underestimated how bold the flavors were, the acidity making the dish sing.  For my entree, I ordered the sliced (bone-in) catfish in a house made chili paste broth off the original Thai style menu.  I was warned the dish would be spicy and thought I could handle it, but boy was I wrong!  The heat was so intense the food was not enjoyable for me.  I also got frustrated picking out the bones and did not enjoy the slimy texture of the catfish skin.  All that said, I recognize that the spiciness and preparation of the fish is actually very authentic and applaud the chef and restaurant for serving such a dish in the US.  My friend's alligator in the same chili paste was also insanely spicy.  

Overall I learned that my American palate can't handle the house made chili paste.  So while it is generally best to try something unique off the original Thai style menu, since I have a low spice tolerance, I should stick with dishes highlighting other spices and lime...
author: Beatrice W.

description:
I've always loved the Lers Ros in Hayes Valley so I was beyond excited to discover that they had a restaurant in the Mission.

I've tried various dishes at this spot but my favorite is still the pork shoulders and the Tom Yum soup. The pork shoulder is so tender and grilled just right. The pad see ew was more mediocre (its pricier than other places but without upping the quality as well) and I find that their non-noodle dishes still taste better than the typical noodle dishes. The Tom Yum is super flavourful though and offer generous portions of shrimp. I also quite like the Tom Yum noodle soup for this reason.

Service is not great here but food quality mostly compares to the Hayes Valley and Tenderloin locations. Ambiance and service is still better at the Hayes Valley location if deciding between locations.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
I'd only just recently discovered the first Lers Ros Thai, so it was a nice surprise to hear that there were 2 others. The third one only opened a couple of weeks ago so I had to try it.

The newest Lers Ros Thai is in the Mission district. It is only open till 10pm Mon-Thur and 11 pm on Fri and Sat.

The interior is shiny and new with a modern look. It should be, the paint is barely dry.

The food is as good as Larkin St. They also have a couple of specials that are only available here.

The service at this location was excellent.

Lers Ros Thai is by far my favorite Thai restaurant in SF, so having 2 more locations to choose from is very welcome news.
author: David T.

description: Our rabbit was bone in, which it did not say on the menu. Soda refills are not free. Service was discombobulated (food that wasn't ours brought to our table, bowls being dropped throughout the restaurant, no offer to look at the dessert menu after the meal was over). Decor is lovely but it is very loud inside. The food menu is varied and interesting, but overall would say it's not worth the wait (20 min for dinner on a Friday) and I would probably not eat there again. Maybe take out.
author: Christina G.

description: We were a group of 6 and went for a late dinner. Was surprised to find frogs and alligator on the menu but didn't have he courage to try those. We ordered chicken fried rice, noodle soup, cashew chicken and sweet and sour chicken, were surprised by the the quick turn around time, and the food tasted fine. Nothing out of the world, but definitely worth it if you are craving Thai food and this one is an option.
author: Rohit K.

description:
I'm rather surprised my review for this spot is just now getting spurned out, considering I attended during the opening week last year, have been here multiple times, my partner is Thai, and we've visited all 3 Lers Ros locations in SF. Ahem!

This review is based upon my most recent visit, which included an out-of-town guest. We all shared the following, family style:

-Koh Moo Yang: Smoky and Tasty! Grilled slices of pork shoulder, with chili and rice powder sauce
-Koong Chae Nam Pla: Fresh raw prawns with chili and lemon grass with lime based salad dressing, served with sliced garlic and mint leaves
-Koong Pad Phed: Full taste of House Made Chili Paste, Kaffir lime leaves, young pepper corn and galingale stir-fried with sliced Prawns
-Thai Herb Sausage: Roasted Thai Northern style herb sausage, served with peanut, cut ginger, sliced red onion, sliced lemon and chili
-Pad Ped Moo Pah: Boar stir-fried with a house made chili paste and galingale
-Sapporro Beer

Hands down, my favorite were the fresh raw prawns. The chili flavors upon them were standout and delish. I also did like the Thai herb sausage, which I was glad at least one item on our table didn't extend beyond my palatable spicy intake zone. (Actually, everything this dining session could fit into that category!)

Now, there is an ongoing debate I have with some about whether or not to eat certain portions of food; one of them is gristle. I am not a fan, but others refer to it as collagen and say, "It's good for you." Good for them! Our boar dish had a bit, as did the pork shoulder, although it was easier to intake on the pork shoulder slices because it was simpler to bite into. I can evolve over time...

The actual meat on the boar was quite flavorful -- I was even impressed by the sliced prawns with chili paste for the same reason. Tickling the taste buds is my ultimate goal, and most dishes here tend to do that. Eating family style, we definitely served up seconds and even thirds for certain dishes (can you guess which?).

Overall, the service was quick, the meal ordered directly in Thai, and this one's closest to home. We will surely be back to continue trying more items from their house- and daily- specials menu. Alligator was a first at Lers Ros for me that way!
author: Garett T.

description:
Came here with two friends at 1pm on MLK day and was greeted by an empty restaurant and the holiday menu.  A slew of issues followed after two of us ordered the pad thai and our other friend ordered the pad see ew.  

First--problems with serving time. The pad see ew came a solid 10 min after the pad thais, so late that the pad thais were only passably warm when we started to eat.  Seriously, 10 minutes when nobody else is around?

Second--inconsistency in serving size.  My friend's pad thai was probably ~30% larger than mine, and both were still pretty darn small (esp. for a dinner price).

Third--meh taste and measly portions.  My plate was half bean sprouts next to a small lump of orange noodles.  There was too much oily sauce, and after I finished there was still a significant amount of grease pooling at the bottom of my plate.  Their ingredient quality was good (chewy noodles, fresh ingredients) but that didn't make up for the other issues.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
World-class Thai food, but I think not even saying that is going to convince you. This is easily Top Five Thai Restaurants of all-time for me, towards the top to number one, and Thai food is the one cuisine I cannot live without. I recently got Yelp compliments for reminding someone about this wonderful place. She said, "You got me drooling. I remember that PORK SHOULDER." I said, yeah, it's on my radar of how popular it's been and I actually haven't gotten to it yet. Still haven't. It's a next-time thing or time after that knowing that I'll have plenty of opportunities ahead of me. My goal is to eat here at "Ler Ros Thai" once a month for the remainder of my life, even with the 70-minute drive handicapping me. Realistically, if I get here half the amount of times planned it will have been a good life.

Anyway, this is my second "Lers Ros" location, and it's in the less hectic location of the Mission District. Favorite item is the off-the-menu item LEK TOM YUM HAENG -- Steamed skinny rice noodles with ground pork, sliced fish cake, crispy pork belly, and dry tom yum noodle, crushed peanuts, burnt crushed chili. Love noodle squishiness, love torrid pork flavors, love the scorched skin and crunchy bites. It's killer good. If you love crispy pork I also recommend the CRISPY PORK BELLY & BASIL, but there's enough crispy pork in the first dish I mentioned that perhaps you can go with something else. GARLIC QUAIL and STEAMED SEABASS WITH LEMONGRASS is on the menu, and I assure you they know what they're doing. The chefs are artists. Also my beer of choice is CHANG and THAI ICED TEA is a good tongue-cooler. Just don't order dishes that you can't get at any old Thai joint, this is not the place to do that at. Pad Thai would be silly of you. #classiceats
author: Sean C.

description: Great food, hearty portions, comfortable environment and pretty easy to find a seat. Go!
author: Mark U.

description:
I loved the one in the tenderloin when I used to live close to there, and am so thrilled that now that I've moved south, there's another one near me. 

This place never disappoints - the crispy pork belly dish is definitely my favorite. Also definitely an indulgent dish. Another must-get is the tom kha soup - gets pRetty spicy (especially since it's hot soup), but is so good. All the curry dishes I've tried are also good, as are the pad see yew and pork chop appetizer 

If you're too lazy to dine in, they also deliver and are pretty fast
author: Amanda L.

description:
I'd failed. It was almost 7:30. My group was hungry and I was to blame. See, I THOUGHT I'd made a reservation somewhere. We'd showed up to that restaurant only to find that my oblivious ass had made a reservation somewhere else, I don't even know,  like...a wine bar or something (wut?). Dammit, Gin! Two giant hungry men and a tiny even more terrifyingly hungry foodie were eyeballing me like "if we can't eat, we kill her". 

So out of a combined love of Thai food and a deep-seeded desire to survive, I stumbled into Lers Ros. The hostess said they were fully booked, but if we promised to eat quickly, she'd be willing to seat us. "Oh...we'll eat quickly" I said. "We'll ravenously destroy our meal so fast that it might actually ruin the appetites of your other patrons". 

K, I didn't really say that. 

But I got the point across! She seated us. 

We ordered hot and sour soup and the spicy thai sausage for appetizers. DESTROYED THEM. In a matter of maybe 45 seconds the table was empty again. And while our hunger may've clouded our ability to accurately gauge the quality of the food, we all agreed that the soup was something akin to liquid heaven if heaven came in soup form and was the perfect level of hot and also a little snippet of sweet. 

I ordered the Green Curry which, when I eat Thai, is always a go-to. So I've had my share of green curry. THIS green curry was incredible. The sliced figs are always a a welcome sight, and the balance of the spice, sweetness, and curry flavor was just...divine. Perfect. Best i've had yet. 

My table ordered a couple of the nights' specials. DESTROYED THEM as well. I mean... we were practically digging into the entrees as the servers were still setting them down. I should be embarrassed to say that. I'm not. The food was that delicious. 

All in all, we left with plenty of time for the hostess. She was actually a little concerned that we'd not even been able to enjoy our food. 

Oh...we enjoyed it, hun. I promise. And thanks. =)
author: Virginia M.

description:
I don't know what it is with Thai food and trying to be fancy. It thought Osha had taken the niche and ran with it, but here is Lers Ros right behind them.  The new Lers Ros in the Mission is quite the boutique Thai Restaurant.  Fancy hip decor, a host up front in a suit that reminds me of the Asian Cowboy from True Blood, and some thumping music in the background.  This is not your grandma's thai restaurant!

With all that being said, this location does live up to the Lers Ros tradition of good Thai food.  We got the duck larb, the papaya salad with raw crab, and the LEK TOM YUM HAENG (a dry rice noodle with ground pork, slice fish cake, plain Crispy Pork Belly). 

The duck larb was on the saltier side and was not as Duckfilled as the Larkin location, but was still declicious and still one of my favorite plates.  The spiciness mixed with the fresh lemon and salt flavors are refreshing and incredibly tasty and goes so will with the savory and crispy duck.  

The papaya salad was solid...the bigger shavings of papaya make it more rustic, which i'm on the fence about.  On the lemonier side as I am more used to the earthier crab/crab paste enriched flavors. The raw crab doesn't disappoint.

The LEK TOM YUM HAENG was quite delcious with the combinations of meat, sauces, and sugar on top (literally). Think 25 dry but heartier, and it didn't even need soup.  They bill it as a dry tom yum, but the flavors are more savory.

Along with the trendy decor and delcious food, the service is also really refined.  The staff is overly eager to help, which is always appreciated, especially when you need more water.... SPICE LEVEL: THAI!
author: Veasna H.

description:
Pretty good Pad Thai at this location. I tend to order Pad Thai at every Thai restaurant I go to in order to compare. It's still not the top in San Francisco, but I'd rate the dish a 4/5 stars. As for the location, very conveniently located.

I would pass on the cream puffs. We added that as an appetizer, but they were simply just dry.
author: Albert K.

description:
I was really surprised that this wasn't better. The downtown location is quite superb. So my hopes were really high.

Honestly, the service was off. I was seated promptly but then forgotten about; was placed at a communal table (I hate those) without being asked about it first, and then sat there a really long time before I flagged down a server... who couldn't take my order... who went to get someone else but that also took quite some time.

The pad kee mao was great; flavors and textures were spot-on, and it was at our table in about three minutes. The gang som, not so great. A little too sour, the flavors lacking complexity, the texture of the chao om a bit too chewy. I've had better. The rabbit was really underwhelming; overcooked, chewy, tons of tiny bones, and a bit bland.

Also, the sticky rice we ordered with our meals came after all three courses were served and we were almost done... but we were sure charged for it, though it sat mostly untouched.

Kitchen Story is number one, Krua Thai is number two, Thai House express is number three, Thai Chef is number four, Thailand Restaurant is number five, and as of now, Lers Ros is my number six choice for Thai food in the Castro area.
author: Sean B.

description: I looked at the Lers Ros website and called in a take-out order for pad makuer tofu, priced $11.95. I go to Lers Ros to pick up my order, and the people working there tell me that the price is $12.95. Upping the price like that is called false advertising. That's called bait and switch. That's called lying. That's called a bad business.
author: Carl S.

description:
Food is not even close to the quality of the original Tenderloin location (which I love).  

What a shame.

Pass.
author: Andrew R.

description: I'm not sure why the Mission location of Ler Ros doesn't get the crowds or positive reviews that their original (TL) version gets, but the food is just as great in my non-expert opinion.  And there's never a wait, which works for me.  My favorites are same as always, larb phed yang (duck larb), and poh tak (tom yum with a mix of seafood rather than just shrimp).  I could have both of these every day and be a happy camper.
author: Joanne G.

description: I used to come here often for lunch, but it seems they may have changed ownership or something in the last few years -- not sure. We ate lunch there the other day. Service was pleasant and it gets two stars for that. However, the meat quality seems to have gone way downhill. I ordered the Green Curry with Pork lunch and chicken satay. The chicken satay was nice and tender, with a nice peanut sauce. The pork meat was disgusting with mostly fat and gristle. I hardly touched it. I mentioned to the waitress that it was no good. We got our bill and paid for it, but reluctantly. No apologies from the kitchen, no comps no nothing. Never going back.
author: P C.

description:
Beautiful decor near the corner of 16th St. & Guerrero. A handful of large tables and several tables for 2.

It's a little pricey relative to other Thai restaurants.  However, the ingredients are good quality, the service is good, and the food is tasty.  The portion sizes are decent so you're not paying higher prices and then getting smaller portions.  I hate it when restaurants do that.  I always feel robbed.

It's been quite a few months since I've been here so honestly, I cannot exactly remember all of the dishes that we tried.  We did order about 5 o 6 dishes.  I do recall that they were all very good and I left the place feeling quite satiated.  In fact, since they were so close to the BART station, it actually occurred to me to grab a take-out menu so that I could BART over during my lunch break and grab my lunch to-go.
