Now if the food weren't good, I'd never even bother picking up a to-go menu especially for a place where I'd have to take a 20 minute BART ride to even get there.

I recall vividly that the food here was very satisfying to my palate so I highly recommend it if you're in the area and are craving Thai food.  In a city like San Francisco where there are thousands of restaurants from various ethnicities, you will find that it is hard for any establishment to survive without a good reason.  Even though I am paying a few dollars more per dish at this restaurant than at another value-priced Thai restaurant, I think it's worth it since the food is quite good.
author: Chrys S.

description:
I got the pad see ew here once and it was pretty good! I've gotten takeout from the Nob Hill location and enjoyed that as well. 

I went back the other night and ordered the chicken soup, and it unfortunately made me sick. I was convinced that the soup probably wasn't what made me sick (I like to think positively, even though it was all I had for dinner, and I am never sick from food...) so I had some leftover soup for lunch the next day. I felt ill all over again and I felt like crap for the rest of the day. :( I won't be back to this location.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I had high expectations for Lers Ros Thai but was disappointed.  

The service was slow and terrible.  We ordered pad see ew, and they brought us pad thai.  The food was mediocre, nothing memorable. 

With all the good restaurants in the Mission, while this was decent, it's not worth coming back.
author: Jaching H.

description:
After finally dining in, I can say the menus are pretty much the same at each location. I opened my menu immediately to noodle soups looking for Kuay Tiew Tom Yum Moo and what do you know? They have it, despite the fact I was told that 1) the menu item numbers are not the same and they don't know them and 2) when I tried to pronounce the noodle soup dish, I was told they don't even make it at this location (yea right) 

I DIGRESS!!!

I was pleasantly surprised to see Sen Lek Tom Yum Haeng on the menu. New special? Don't recall seeing it in the Tenderloin.. Perhaps new? i could be wrong. The description on the menu said Thai hot and sour noodles but it's pretty much tom yum noodles, dry. Loved it since I am a fan of dry boat noodles. Extremely filling since they give you a bunch of meats, lots of noodles with a hint of that tom yum taste although it leaned more on the sweet, tamarind side. 


Still not really getting the spicy thing right (frustrating). We asked for our pad thai spicy and got it kind of bland. Listen, I understand that the Thai level of spicy is intense and can be hard to handle but we did ask for spicy... This seems to be a recurring issue for me.

Need to come back and dine in again for yum woon sen and kuay jub.
author: Susy C.

description: Not good Thai food... I got pad Thai and my friend got sweet and sour chicken. My pad Thai way way too sweet it tasted like a different dish due to the excess sugar and his chicken was very dry . Pretty basic dishes done wrong
author: Lynn L.

description:
So happy they opened a location near me.

Had the green curry with sticky rice and it was great. Had a good spice kick to it. Also had the frog legs.. the meat was VERY chewy, especially since it was fried. But they were generous with the garlic and such.

The fried rice with crispy chicken on top was also really good. Huge portions! My friend had the bbq chicken as well and it was literally 3/4 or a whole chicken.

Will be coming back lots of times!
author: Angela L.

description:
Came here today - first time at this location which is pretty new.

The ambiance is much more hip and upscale as compared to the one in the Tenderloin. The music is Top 40 upbeat pop. 

Got some Prawns with Asparagus, Chicken Pad Thai, and Beef Kra Pow. Washed down with a Thai Ice Coffee.

Parking is a b---- here, btw.

Grab a Pliny from Monk's Kettle afterwards which is down the street.
author: Julia P.

description:
Tired of over priced, inauthentic, small portions of food!

Tried the Duck Laarb Salad.

Um.. not worth the price.  Very one noted in flavor profile.  Also, the duck meat took on a mushy liver-like consistency with the acid from the lime juice.
author: Chapstiq G.

description:
2.75 stars 

Silly me, I don't often use Yelp as a resource for info, I read (& obviously write) reviews because I find them entertaining & mouthwatering; food erotica, if you will. These days, I prefer to experience a restaurant first-hand & then go back & read what my favorites had to say (way to do things backwards!) 

Following dinner at Lers Ros, I read over some of my yelp homies' reviews & found a barrage of 4-star reviews. To this, I say two things: I'm envious of your nom-able experience, & did we eat at the same restaurant?! We ordered: 

-- Thai iced teas & sides of sticky rice -- the usual 
-- tom yum koong which had a lovely presentation served out of an iron hot pot, but unfortunately i believe we were served tom kah kai. We intentionally didn't order this coconut milk-based soup. Was sufficiently spicy, had plenty of lime, but wasn't the flavor we anticipated. 
-- kai pad khing: sliced chicken stir fried w/ ginger, onions, & mushrooms. I found the preparation extremely odd. I like my protein dishes to either be dry or have a full-bodied sauce I can spoon over rice/noodles; this one had a watery, flavorless liquid that barely covered the bottom of the plate. 
-- we ordered a fish dish off of the specials menu, but were informed 20 minutes later that they didn't have the ingredients but that they'd make us another dish, cod with black bean sauce. We were so over the whole experience that we just agreed & thought, well, let's see what they come up with. Was the most expensive dish we ordered, as well as the most unmemorable. 

Either because of my own poor choosing skills or Lers Ros' inability to deliver what we originally ordered, we didn't get anything we wanted out of a restaurant that night.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
TL;DR Flavors were great, the meat was a little too fatty, and the service was ok.

I made a reservation for 2 on a Saturday night at 7 and I don't think it was necessary. There were plenty of seats available inside the spacious restaurant. It didn't feel too crowded, even after the restaurant started filling in. Also, this location seems good for groups (presumably with a reservation).

I ordered the Rad Nah (flat noodle with gravy), the Kang Phed Yang (red curry with duck), and the crab roll cake as an appetizer. The noodles and the curry had great flavors, but the meats (both pork and duck) were too fatty, and the overall portions were smaller than I expected. The crab roll cakes were fantastic as an appetizer.

I was a little disappointed with the service. They were too eager to clear plates out of the way. For instance, I took the last crab roll cake from the serving dish and before I could dip it in the sauce, it was taken away! I appreciate the attentiveness, but when I can't finish the food without feeling rushed, it's a little frustrating.

Overall, I liked Lers Ros and would try it again.
author: Edwin C.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Thailand a few months ago and this is the closest version of authentic Thai food in SF.

The pad thai is usually a good indicator and I love theirs. Go for the papaya salad, too.
author: Susie R.

description:
The food and service was quite good. Our table of four were all quite happy with their dishes. The best, though, were the desserts. My friend and I shared a sticky rice with mango and fried banana with ice cream.

It was good to get there early because it eventually became quite busy and a little noisy.
author: Leslie K.

description: Stopped by the new Lers Ros Thai restaurant in the Mission for lunch.  They have a lunch menu where you choose two main options, house salad, and rice for $10.  I went around 1PM on a Thursday.  The place was about half full.  The staff was very friendly and sat my friend and me right away.  I got a double pad kra prow with brown rice.  It was delicious.  The perfect combination of spicy, sweet, savory, and fresh with a good amount of thai basil, garlic, peppers, and minced chicken.  The house salad was good.  The dressing was fresh and definitely had a thai flavor profile.  A bit sweet for me.  Overall a great experience with delicious thai food for lunch for about $13 with tax and tip.
author: Paul W.

description: The food has been pretty good here.  However the food is never served together.  One dish is served then 10-15 mins later another persons food comes out.  Ruins the dining experience.  The wait staff doesn't know proper serving etiquette.  Bringing food out for two people shouldn't be that challenging.
author: Kevin C.

description: This place is legit. I love Thai curry and this was honestly some of the best I've ever had. I got the yellow curry with potatoes and shrimp, Boyfriend got one of the specials with shrimp fried rice. Both were AMAZING. The jasmine tea and Thai iced were good too. Nothing overly special but still delicious. Not crowded, the food came fast and nice size portions. Going back again tonight and can't wait
author: Sheldon B.

description:
Christopher Columbus would be proud of our dining exploration (new spot on opening day). Or my fave quote from "Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby"- "If you're not first, you're last. Shake and bake!"

Chill space, wooden tables, dim lighting, and ceiling decor of wooden branches  (Mission space is smaller than Hayes and fancier than the original Tenderloin).

We ordered raw blue crab papaya salad, gator w/ fresh peppercorn, deep fried trout w/ mango salad, pork belly w/ Chinese broccoli, and hot & sour pork ribs soup.

My unwavering swine love was compromised by the raw blue crab. NY has fantastic Korean and Lers is the only SF place to dine on these deliciousness! While my companions threw in the towel, my inner triathl(EAT) aka hollow leg will rally! Forget gold, platinum eater all the way, baby!
author: Sophie C.

description:
We came for opening day. Amazing food, amazing service, and awesome new location. 

We started out with a bottle of white wine, which was served in a chilled bucket...nice touch : )

For a starter we had the chicken larb. Delish! A bit on the spicy side, but we love spicy food so it was awesome. Great amount of citrus. 

Next we had the famous crispy pork belly dish and pad se ew. Both we're amazing. The pork belly was so crispy and flavorful it was out of this world! Most perfectly cooked pork belly I've ever had. My bf said the pad se ew was the best he's ever tasted, and pad se ew is his go to thai favorite. 

The decor is perfect. Very on point with the other two locations. Every detail is perfect from the fresh flowers to the amazing lighting. 

We're so excited so have this new amazing addition to our neighborhood! Thanks for a great evening : )
author: Juliet S.

description: Went there with a party of 4. We had the Pad Thai (better than other Pad Thais I had in other restaurants in California, although it was not perfect because I was a little too sweet for my liking. Then we also had the Crispy Chicken on Fried Rice (the chicken was great, the fried rice pretty standard, but good), the stewed pork (we've never had this before, and it was very tasty; sweet and fell right off the bone) and the papaya salad, my best friend's favorite. Everything tasted great, portions are fair, presentation simple but colorful and tempting. Did not feel like dessert, maybe next time!
author: Pancho M.

description: Came for lunch. First time, last time. Can you say bland? Ate with two friends, also first timers. We all had simple dishes, yellow curry, combo lunch special, and a cashew nut chicken. Curry was bland, but somehow overspiced. Way overspiced, as I like me some good spice, but I also like some flavor. Nothing like that. The cashew chicken was a tragedy. Boring hardly cuts it. Way too many carrots, barely a trace of onions, and nothing else. No red or green pepper, no celery, no nothing. Boring, and bland. And the service was ridiculously slow, especially given that there were three of us and just two other full tables, a two-top and a four top. The four top cashed out just after we ordered, so you'd think the staff would have it easy, but they vanished without a trace until the end of the meal, and only came when we flagged them down. Sorry kids, there are just too many good Thai restaurants in town to go here.
author: Mona M.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Lers Ros the other night after scoping it out for months - he's always trying to taste some alligator. The ambiance was very cool and minimally decorated. All of the waiters were very friendly, but spoke minimal english (pretty normal here in sf).

We got a sweet and spicy seafood soup over a flaming bowl that I absolutely loved; they didn't hold back on the amount and variety of seafood, and it was flavored so well and sinus clearingly spicy. So good. 

The rest of our food was good but not great. We got the garlic quail and garlic frog appetizers (we just couldn't decide lol) which tasted almost exactly the same. The alligator entree was good too but highlighted the curry way more than the unique meat.

We'll likely go back for another adventurous night, even though it didn't knock my socks off.
author: Medina C.

description:
Three reasons I chose Lers Ros Thai and the Mission location, 1) The health score on yelp - 98 out of 100, 2) Koong Chae Nam Pla, and 3) their soup comes in a flamming pot.

I don't know of any other Thai restaurant that offers "Koong Chae Nam Pla" - Fresh raw prawns with chili and lemon grass with lime based salad dressing, served with sliced garlic and mint leaves.  I researched for a long time and only Lers Ros Thai has it.  I am not a big fan of lime/lemon juice but the combination of chili, lemon grass, garlic, and mint leaves with the raw prawns blended in so well I have no problem with the acidity of the dressing.

Both dishes (Pad Kee Mow - Spicy pan-fried flat noodle with basil, bell peppers, bean sprouts, and beef) and (Kang Karee - Yellow Curry with Pork) both on the sweeter side.

The overall taste of "Tom Kha Kai" (Coconut milk based soup with Chicken , lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves) was full of coconut flavor but didn't overwhelm the soup itself, although it's a bit on the sour side for me.  My companion found it to be just right and very tasty.  It came in a flamming pot to keep the soup warm which is a must and I found no other restaurants in the neighborhood offer that.

We had no problem with the service and no need to wait either on a Sat. compare to the more popular one at the tenderloion location.

Overall 3.5 stars.
author: Shirley H.

description: I just can't seem to find blow my mind Thai food in this city.  It's all just OK here.  No dish stands out.  Flavors are either make you cry spicy or make you fall asleep muted.
author: Kamael S.

description:
Thai places are all over SF, but a Thai restaurant in the Mission? Not so much. My bf wanted to grab dinner here one night, and it looked pretty cool inside, so we checked it out.

Service: We were promptly seated at a table for two and they took our drink orders. They were very attentive, check in on us, but not interrupting. 

Food: They didn't have spring rolls, so we defaulted to Koh Moo Yang (grilled slices of pork shoulder). We were happy we did because it was pretty good! I wasn't a big fan of how much fat was left on each slice, especially with no knife to cut it off, but it went with the sauce well. We also ordered the Kang Daeng with beef and Moo Preaw Warn. We also got an order of jasmine rice and jasmine brown rice. The curry was pretty good, especially since it had a good kick to it, and I'm a fan of the jasmine brown rice (I didn't realize this was a thing now). The Moo Preaw Warn was also pretty good, but not my favorite.

Ambiance: Cute date night place, but also good for moderately sized groups. It does get a little loud with the music and hum of conversation throughout the restaurant, but nothing we couldn't talk over.

Drinks: They have a pretty decent drink menu and a cool display of wines on the back wall, but we just ordered a couple of beers.

Would I come back? Possibly. It's a pretty solid restaurant with a good ambiance, good service, and decently priced!
author: Leana L.

description: Super nice and accommodating - came with a group of 20+ after church on Sunday. For those with strict no-oil diets like me, they can do a good steamed chicken and veggies for you. Portions are big too!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Well, my mother (and Walt Disney) always taught me that if I don't have something nice to say, I shouldn't say nothin' at all, buuuut I must stay true to my cold-blooded roots, and be honest. I was craving some spicy green curry and wanted to branch out from the go-to spot. Let me just say that SIMPLY ORDERING was a huge headache, and here's why, folks:

1) Called the number listed on their website, it was busy the first 5 times I called, then it turns out this location is on Larkin, and being in the Mission, I was too far for delivery, so the employee advised me to call the 16th St location and gave the other number listed on their site.

2) Called the second number, busy the first few calls, then the woman says we need to call the Mission location (??); um, we just did?

3) A new number is given so quickly and then the phone disconnects, call back: BUSY!

4) FINALLY get ahold of someone at the Mission location, give the woman my address, spelling it out three times before angrily handing the phone to my more patient better-half. He gives the address slowly, along with cross street (Caesar Chavez), to which the lady tries to read back, and gets wrong, doesn't seem to know what Caesar Chavez is... okay they just opened this location 2 weeks ago, so I guess it's understandable.

5) He begins to order off the menu on their website, which is numbered, so he orders the #66 (Tom Yum w/ pork and noodles), she says they don't use numbers at the restaurant to order, so he reads off the name Kuay Tiew Tom Yum Moo, she asks him to spell it out, so he does, and she doesn't know what it is and asks if he wants hot and sour soup? He's not sure at this point if it could be a h&s soup, so he asks for the soup by name and again spells it out, and then, click! She knows just what he's talking about! 

Ordering the rest of the food was about as much trouble, but taking his credit card number was a breeze! Then, not 5 mintues after hanging up, the woman calls back and asks him to spell out the address again! Just silliness, IMPLEMENT ONLINE ORDERING!!

The food arrived quickly and his soup and Yum Woon Sen were good, my green curry was very spicy and gave me heartburn (my own fault, but definitely added to my distaste for this place). I still may go back, and dine in because the Duck Larb and the rest of the menu sounds good.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Meh meh meh. Super disappointing all around. The food was just really unremarkable. We had the Pad Thai, Pad Woon Sen, and Tom Yum soup. The noodle dishes were greasy and relatively flavorless and the Tom Yum was way too salty. Left wishing I had the $40 back. 

In addition, the ambiance was just so-so. When we got there we were four of six total diners in the restaurant and despite there being 10 servers and hosts it took 20 minutes for one of them to come by and take our order. Before we ordered we had to change tables because our original one (back right corner) had a distinct bathroom smell wafting around it. After we did finally order the food came out sporadically which really interrupted the flow of our dinner.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Was excited that they opened a new location in the Mission so I was eager to try it with a friend for lunch. Lunch time is easier to find parking and the restaurant was not as busy as the other locations. The food is up to par as the other 2 locations. My fav is papaya salad with shrimp and their stir fried pork belly. I am glad I have a closer location when I am craving for Thai food! 

The price is on the higher side but hey, I think people in SF Mission area should be used to it by now. Mission has become the place where all restaurant owners want to open their business at. Even King of Thai prices is comparable to Lers Ros Thai.
author: Kapo T.

description: I love Lers Ros, but when I asked for an update on my Caviar order, which hello I'm still paying Lers Ros for and am a customer of, the rude rude lady refused to look to see whether my order was ready. She said she had 30 orders during the day (how does that apply to my order within the last hour?) and didn't have time to help me. In the time she could have looked, she chose to argue with me and had no empathy that my order was 20 minutes past due. I am not ordering from them any more since they clearly do not value their customers.
author: Jess B.

description:
There are places you go to, to be taken care of by the servers. So eager are they to give you an Experience you could hypothetically ask to be spoon fed and they would have to at least humor you. I was not looking to be spoon fed. I was looking for delicious Thai food. And delicious Thai food did I receive. 

*there was a spoon - I used it to spoon feed myself. 
**because you do always want to feel special.
author: Ryley P.

description: I ordered takeout on May 8 and am glad that I didn't get sick after eating Lers Ros's food. Not only was the service bad - the server seemed annoyed and distracted about something, failing to even say thank you after I paid - but the food was truly awful. Inedible, actually. After a few bites, we threw away the greasy brown glob of Pad See-Ew. The chicken satay was slimy and had an off taste, the fried rice with crispy chicken had little flavor but an abundance of grease. I could go on and on, but this was really the worse food I have ever paid for.  I so regretted coming here.
author: lucia c.

description:
third location, but the prices are up since the heyday of 2009 TL location and consistency slightly down.  just had two noodle soups:
Kuay Tiew Rua boat noodles, which has a different broth at this location, less tangy, less concentrated broth but at least still with some earthy depth.  noodles way limp and overdone.
Kuay Jub with five spice broth, on the sweet side, had to add spice.  nice crispy pork belly pieces, lots of entrails, but rolled noodle still kinda dry (compared to handmade noodle)
author: Rob C.

description: Meh. A couple of friends who had been before said it was quite good and a bit upscale. Sure, it's not as casual as most Thai restaurants, but it wasn't great. The food is marginally better than most Thai restaurants in the City. What killed it for me was the LOUD space (music playing as well as tile floors and walls), crowded tables, and mediocre service.
author: Mark V.

description:
It was my first Thai dish, and I'm so happy I found this place. The atmosphere was really nice; the interior was really minimalistic and I loved the wooden seating ad tables. 

I ordered Pad Thai, but considering I was the only one there, I wasn't surprised about the short wait. Regardless, the food was incredible and well presented. Even when more and more people came walking in, I noticed they weren't kept waiting more than 10mins after ordering.

I definitely recommend this place to anyone who's looking for something different!
author: Danny M.

description:
Admittedly, my friend and I were interested in getting some "boring" dishes.  I've tried the frog and alligator at the TL location, and we just wanted some regular Thai dishes for dinner this time around.  Pad kee mao was as expected (spicy and tasty).  The stir fried pork belly was a bit fatty, but I guess that's what you get when you order pork belly.  :)

Nothing spectacular food-wise, but an extra star for friendly service and the fact that this was a nice place in the Mission that we could linger for 2.5 hours while paying $14 each.
author: Melinda C.

description: I'm surprised that people are not giving this place a better review.  I have very high standards when it comes to Thai food.  I've been to Thailand multiple times, took several Thai cooking classes and generally have pretty distinguished taste.  The quality of food here is awesome and you could find unique and unusual dishes here that may not be available at other Thai restaurants.  Basically, I love the food here and would highly recommend this
author: Regina C.

description:
So I finally decided to try this Lers Ros last night after realizing that the previous Thai restaurant was truly gone.

This place place is LOUD. I could barely hear the waiter, the server, or my dining partner. I could hear the conversation at the table next to me because I think they were shouting.

Our order came in the oddest order: side dish, rice, entree, noodles, and finally drinks that we ordered first. They serve your rice onto your plate, but it is not helpful when you don't have anything substantial to eat with it, so it started getting cold while waiting for the rest of the food to arrive. My drink was supposed to have light ice, but apparently it went to the table next to us and I got a drink with extra ice. Speaking of ice and water, this restaurant apparently did not get the drought memo and brought us two large glasses of ice water without us asking for them, they also filled my water glass one more time, but made sure I got a lot of ice.

Enough about service, I'll dish on one and only one dish, the Pad Thai with shrimp. I think there were extra bean sprouts as a filler because there was a slightly bitter taste with the dish. The worst part were the shrimp which were not fresh and tasted fishy.

I've been to the locations in the Tenderloin and Hayes Valley, both of these locations are decent, but I don't know why this place wasn't. I'm also trying to figure out why the place could easily change signs and become an Osha Thai if it had to. Is there a reason a Thai restaurant needs to feel like a club? It's just Thai food!
author: Steve A.

description: Nice ambiance and a broad menu with some dishes that you can't get at many other Thai restaurants. But the quality of the ingredients just isn't there. I recently ordered a pork pad see-ew, and the "pork" was just a single tangled mass of gristle (see photo I posted). Pretty gross.
author: David C.

description: Really good yellow curry. I had the vegetarian curry and it was pretty loaded with vegetables and tofu which I appreciated. Staff was also really nice and the place itself was lovely.
author: Rebeccah Y.

description:
I went here with friends last week and had a great dining experience. 

We had reservations for dinner at 7:30 but found the restaurant nearly empty. It was a Monday night and 4/20 so maybe that had something to do with the slow traffic. Service was slow at first but once we ordered, they were quite attentive. 


Our eyes may have been bigger than our stomachs but I'm glad we got try a variety of dishes here. To start, we ordered the Moo Phing (BBQ pork) and the curry turnovers (can't remember the real name). The turnovers were delicious!! They had the perfect balance of flavors. The BBQ pork was a hit with my friends but I wasn't too crazy about it. It was seasoned with a spice that reminded me of goat meat (which I love)  and confused my taste buds. For entrees we ordered the papaya salad, chicken pad see ew, crispy pork belly and the Lek Tom Yum Haeng. All were delicious but the pork belly and the pad see ew took top prize.
author: Bukky E.

description:
The server greeted us right away, although she was clearing up a table with plates and condiments in her hands. 

Good Service ****

Ordered 

Pork Shoulder **** 
Loved the sauce and the pork was tender with a crispy edge 

Pork Skewers *
I would not order this again. It was one huge piece of over cooked old meat on a stick 

Pad Thai ***
The pad Thai was on the sweeter side but everything was made very well. Tasty prawns 

Chicken with sticky rice special  ***
The chicken was dry but nicely seasoned with a good combination. The salad was very refreshing and gave everything a good crunch
author: Sylvia C.

description:
I don't write many Yelp reviews but I'd like to think my verbal reviews to friends are legendary and somewhat respected. The reason I decided to write this review is because though I am neither a human rights or animal rights activist I would be condemning others to the same culinary death if I don't fire a warning shot. After all, as Kobe told us, we "can't just stand by and watch crime happen".

I've eaten at all 3 SF Lers Ros locations many times but I'll never order from the 16th location again. I ordered food for delivery on a Friday night, delivery time was fine, driver was polite so no problems there. The problems started when I closed the front door and opened the pad see ew in an enclosed area (my house), it was at this time I found out that Lers Ros had Trojan horsed me. The smell of rancid garlic filled my house like an unwelcome friend crashing on the couch eating sauerkraut. I opened the sliced pork shoulder to find that it was not sliced. It was not sliced because it was so over cooked and fatty that the chef was not able to cut through it, only at it. I won't bore you with the rest, the food was bad and ruined my appetite so obviously I didn't eat it.

I called back the next day (which I hate to do) and experienced the dreadful customer service you'd expect. From the moment I began talking to the person who was supposed to be the manager (Bil) she treated me as if I was Bernie Madoff trying to use free pad see ew to fuel my ponsi scheme. After telling her my phone number twice, she reviewed my order twice, and then asked me to tell her what was wrong with each dish...twice. The next step of course was to say hold on, make me wait for 5 minutes and then come back to say that she was not the manager, she is just a "worker", and couldn't do anything for me. She told me to email lersros at hotmail, seriously. I said ok and hung up the phone. It was at this time I realized I had a responsibility as a human to save others from this fate. I called her back and told her I wasn't going to tell my story over email again so it could go unanswered, instead of be taking my talents to yelp. My statement was met with a complete change of attitude and  it turned out she could do anything I wanted after all. She told me she'd give me 50% off another order. I told her no thanks and that instead I'd like to make a return of the actual food so that she could taste it. I wasn't there but I'm pretty sure she fell off her chair that it turned out I was telling the truth and not trying to get free food. She sent me a duplicate order for free.

I've been treated rudely before but I've never had a restaurant manager waste 30 mins of my time to lie to me. I understand that some people might think that sending me new food after all of this constitutes good service but that's not me. I don't like being treated like a con artist and I value my time. If you like good food and you value your time then consider yourself warned.

Sincerely,

Not Cliff, or maybe I am Cliff, I guess it depends if you're gonna yelp me or not
author: Cliff D.

description: very very bad service and food i never tried,and they dont have any parking area,you.have to pay it .wont go ever...
author: Andy X.

description: There is a lot of good Thai food in San Francisco and especially within a one block radius of this place. I've been to all the Lers Ros locations and this is definitely solid -- better than Hayes. The bbq chicken was finger lickin' good as was the red curry duck. Nice service and atmosphere and the price was right.
author: Andrew K.

description: This place came with a lot of food for the price. I was a little sad they didn't serve soup ind. and I couldn't add and the salad dressing was not as good as I thought. I liked the Kao Kai Yang but the ends of the chicken skewer tasted dry. I gave a 3 cause service was great but sad it was nothing like Thai House 530.
author: Jess C.

description: This place is awesome and accommodates large parties.  The service is nice and friendly.  Very efficient.  The venue is pretty nice and new.  The new menu is great and was pretty good.  $12 corkage fee per bottle so bring your own wine.
author: Chris L.

description:
First, I have to say, I am biased.  I do not like spicy and greasy food.
So this place is not really for me.  But if you are a big fan of the above stated, this is probably the place for you.  The spicy it is Thai spicy, not American spicy.

Talking about ambiance, the heart pumping music was a bit too loud for a date night, cannot hear what my partner was talking about.  It is like being at a gym.
author: Yi Z.

description:
This is a great find in the neighborhood and in a good location in the Mission.
Right after we finished dinner on our way out, a tour bus of like 30 people showed up! 
I actually commented during dinner that the wait was really not bad at all since we didn't have any reservations. Bathrooms were clean, too!

Food was fantastic. It really had a lot of flavor and a certain sophistication that you don't always find at a Thai restaurant. We were a party of three on a GNO in the Mission and one of them heard of this place on the plane from NY.

What we ordered**:

Rockfish with Thai eggplant (size of Tomatillos, green skin, soft pale yellow flesh--not purple), various vegetables and garnished with fresh peppercorns. This is a good dish if you like fish and want a dish that is not spicy. The fish had a firmness to it and held up in the dish. The Thai eggplant has a bit of a crunch to it. A cross between an eggplant and a zucchini.

Vegetarian Red Curry (Kang Deng) - We had this curry with Thai eggplant and Tofu.
It really needed to feature the eggplant and Tofu more since it was vegetarian. But the curry was excellent with a little kick to it so be prepared. We had ours with brown rice. Our hostess explained that the Red Curries were medium spicy.

Pad Thai - Some dishes you just expect to be good because it's a standard. This is one of them. Theirs is really good. It was light, not heavy. I could eat this every day of the week. However, ours needed more shrimp. 

**No drinks or dessert but there's always another time, right? Bill was $60 with tip.
We ate family-style and shared all the dishes.
author: Lina L.

description:
We met up with some friends here on a Friday night, and had a meal so good I had dreams about it later that night.

We ordered
- Nuer Tod: Fried-sun-dried beef, served with chili and rice powder sauce 
- Larb Phed Yang: A chunk of roasted duck mixed with rice powder, chili powder and lime based salad dressing
- Tom Kreang Nai: House special broth with pork entrails, preserved green mustard; served with house secret chili, garlic & vinegar sauce
- Pad Kee Mow 
- Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob: Stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and Basil leaves
- Nuer Pad Prik: Tender beef, stir-fried with chili paste, bell peppers, bamboo shoot, basil
-Side of garlic & ginger rice

If you go, try to go with a bunch of people so you can share a wide variety of dishes. They have a menu that is really much more diverse than traditional Thai restaurants. Lots of ingredients and dishes I've never seen before. I'm convinced everything on their menu is dericious.

Overall, this is my fave Thai restaurant in SF. This location is fairly new and since it is in the Mission, parking can be hard. But go here if you want to explore exotic Thai dishes and pair it with wine, beer, and sake too for a fun time!
author: Veronica T.

description:
We have tried different dishes in the past few months. Our conclusion is they can't cook meat well. They do have $10 lunch special menu, but nothing interests us to order. 

Kai Yang: It tastes like Costco roast chicken. Don't wast $.
Pepper corn sauteed beef: very stiff. My denture almost came out from my mouth.
Shrimp paste fried rice: super good. A+++++. Must have!
Minced cat fish mango salad: good
Crab fried rice: good
Squid salad: good
Duck salad (larb): good
Seafood medley: good, but a bit salty.
Pad see U Beef: mediocre. I passed. Beef was so stiff. 
Tom Yum dried noodles: good
Garlic & Ginger fried rice with crispy chicken: just OK. I won't order this again. The rice tasted like 'hai nam' chicken rice.

The restaurant is only two blocks away from our office. We basically come here once a week. Even we are a regular, please do not assume we receive good services. I flagged the waitress to refill our water a couple times. Finally, someone came. There were 5 of us eating here today, but only two people got their water refilled. What's happened to the other three???  I asked for the check twice when the waitress was refilling water, she didn't respond to me and walked away. Did you hear me or not? 30 seconds later, she put down our check. Service is basically non-existence here. Don't bring your business clients or dates to here. You won't be able to impress your guests. 

The amount of money we spend should be equal to the service we receive.  We usually pay $20 for lunch here. With the minimal service we receive, I take out two stars for bad service.
author: J L.

description:
Wow - what an absolute awesome find!

Ordered deliver for a work team dinner and we were very pleased with our selections. Our choices ranged from the fried roll and chicken satay for appetizers to yellow curry with chicken and green curry with shrimp. Beware - that green curry is super hot! Pad Thai was delicious - we had both chicken and shrimp options. 

All in all, this place is impressive. Yummy and Spicy. 

Can't wait to try it again.
bon appétit!
author: Wendy P.

description:
I'm pretty sure I've ordered To-Go from the Tenderloin....but because I can't remember, I came to the Mission location for a sit-down dinner.

This location is conveniently located a block or so away from 16th Mission Bart station. The decor of this place is very swanky and has a nice vibe to it. It gets pretty loud in here, so if you're looking for an intimate and quiet date spot...you'll need to look elsewhere. 

We had a reservation for 2 and were seated quite promptly. We ordered:

- Shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, lime based salad dressing & grilled prawns-- spicy
- Stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and Basil leaves
- Warm House Sake

Absolutely LOVED the pork belly...! I highly recommend you order it at this location if you're not a vegetarian. The green papaya salad was very delicious as well and SPICY was amazing. If you're not afraid of the heat, get spicy!

Only mishap we had was that we ordered a bowl of brown rice, and we never got it. We had asked about it twice throughout the night and were never given a bowl, haha. Finally, we just gave up. However, when we got the bill, we were charged for a bowl of brown rice...so we had to get that corrected. 

In any case, not a bad place to come for dinner. I'll have to remember to go to the Tenderloin location for a sit-down dinner next time!
author: Rachel C.

description:
Great change from your typical Thai restaurant. 

Must get the Duck Larb!!!!

Dishes are authentic and satisfying. I will definitely be back!
author: Charisa N.

description:
I've only been to this place twice, both times for lunch. The service is ok, not friendly but efficient. The food I've been served both times could only come from an indifferent kitchen. The salad was sad and tired, and I could make better yellow curry at home. Same for the broccoli dish. The brown rice was nice.

Indifferent is the word I'd use to describe the decor and atmosphere of this place. And they need to put a coat hook or two in the bathroom/storage room.
author: Carolyn S.

description: I am a fan!  Came in here with my friend from Chicago.  We both didn't order a lot but both dishes we had were wonderful.  We came in here on a Sat and we got sat immediately.   Staff was friendly and nice.  I enjoyed it very much.
author: Aug C.

description: Wanted to love it. Came in on a blustery day but the soup was salty and overly garlicky.  Not delicious. Merely okay. Seemed popular and boisterous. Next time I'll have Thai elsewhere.
author: Thalia F.

description:
This classy Thai place is definitely a must-try if you're in San Francisco. I've been here twice so far.. and the first time, I was a little iffy about coming back... but the second time-- which took place yesterday, was great. The problem with the first time was that I was only able to enjoy two dishes with a couple of appetizers.. which didn't really go well together. The second time, I went with more people and got to try more things together. So, I think that if you want the most out of the Lers Ros experience, you have to order family style (three or more dishes)-- which is the way Thai food should be eaten.

I love the papaya salad-- which is not done in the usual mixed way. It comes with a side of cabbage and the papaya (mixed in that amazing spicy fish sauce). I've had this both times-- once with prawn, and the other with raw crab-- definitely go with the raw crab. Another great dish was the shrimp paste fried rice, which was one of the specials of the day-- but it should go on the main menu because it is so good! It was definitely my favorite dish of the night.

In general, everything is on the pricier side of things-- because you're sort of paying for the ambiance (and a very nice ambiance at that)... as well as the quality of the food. You should definitely look this place up if you've got a couple of friends for dinner (because you get to try a couple more dishes, creating a more complete meal). However, the other Lers Ros Thai place (in the Tenderloin) may be better.. but busier!
author: Julie H.

description: Got the kuay jub, which is a noodle soup with entrails and crispy pork belly.  You have the option of getting clear or dark broth, and the dark broth is delicious, both sweet and salty.  The toppings were great, although i probably would have preferred long noodles instead of the square ones that come in this dish.  For under $9, this was a great deal.
author: Simon L.

description:
I am taking away one star for terrible service. 

The rant first: 
We made a reservation for a party of three at 8 pm. Well, when we got there around 8:05 pm, and were told that the previous party was just paying and leaving. And well, we waited until 8:30 pm without any indication on whether we'd be seated soon. Sure, the waitstaff can't control when the party leaves, but we would have liked to have been asked whether we wanted some drinks while we were waiting. When we were seated, we were understandably incredibly hungry. But for some reason, our waitress did not come to take our order for the next ten minutes (...because we needed more time to decide on what we wanted after 30 minutes of looking at the menu?). 

On food (4 stars): 
House special - boar: I am not a big fan of boar because of its distinct texture. The seasoning was pretty spicy and nice, but the meat wasn't high quality. There were big chunks of rubbery fat, and there really wasn't much meat to start with because 80% of the dish was covered with spices and not very appetizing-looking vegetables.      

Pad see ew with beef: The noodles were cooked well and seasoned thoroughly. The quality of meat wasn't the best, but it wasn't expected to be great any way. This had a very mild spicy kick to it, which was definitely different from most Americanized Thai restaurants that make this dish soy-sauce-sweet.   

Red curry with duck: I wish that the portion size were bigger. There weren't much duck meat in the curry but the vegetables were crunchy and nice. The curry itself had nice coconut flavor and was very flavorful.   
   
It is definitely the best Thai place I've been to in the bay area in terms of flavors, but I wished that the portion size would be larger.
author: Wonhee P.

description:
Very good quality food.  Unique choices: duck, alligator, frog, boar.  Perfectly cooked :)

Decor is upscale.  Good chill/popular music.  

Prices were reasonable, service was prompt and friendly.
author: J. G.

description: This is your run of the mill Thai food for the masses. The flavors are muddled, and overly sweet, but their lunch specials are a good deal.
author: K C.

description: Had the duck larb salad which is always delicious with strong lime and basil notes. Had the beef pad prix which has a wonderfully rich, peppery flavor profile. Tried the venison tonight and loved the curry flavor but found the meat to dry/chewy for my taste. Washed everything down with 2 tall sanghas :) service had a bit to be desired as they were clearly preoccupied with a large group that was supposed to be arriving. Had to flag down service. Oh well their portions and prices are pretty good and the favor u can't compete with. Debating whether to try the rabbit next time... All In all their food is excellent.
author: Jordan Q.

description: Duck larb salad is life changing. One of the best thai places in the city both for classic dishes as well as their specials.
author: Katherine W.

description: Been here several times and have always loved their Pad Thai. My husband and I were craving it so bad that we drove 30 minutes in the rain to get it, and the food tasted like it came from a completely different restaurant. The Pad Thai was totally dry, flavorless, and oily. It went from being some of the best Pad Thai I've had, to some of the worst. Really wish I could have gotten my money back for this meal. Definitely not worth my time or money for pick up
author: Rachel C.

description:
I ate here the other night on a Tuesday. We just ordered the drunken noodle and the rabbit special. The drunken noodle was average and the rabbit was horrible. It was small chunks of bone and meat which had clearly been thrown in the fryer for way too long, it was like eating a tire with boney needles in it, I couldn't even swallow it, lest I choke or get a laceration in my esophagus. When I told the waitress about the over cooking she asked me if I had ever eaten rabbit before. I was quite offended, as rabbit should be a tender meat, and anyways, the customer is always (well, usually) right.

No refund or replacement offered. And it was the most expensive dish on the menu to top it off, never going here again. I'll stick to Krua across the street, they are way more consistent.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
The Pan Phed Venison (venison stir-fried with a thin coconut milk and house made chili paste, thai eggplant, young pepper corn & galingale) was delicious but hella spicy.  Also got the yellow coconut curry w/ chicken (Kang Karee) which was perfect.

Finally, a good Thai place that delivers to Potrero Hill!  Goodbye forever, Grand Pu Bah!  You sucked!

Here's an interesting interview with Tom Silargorn, the chef/owner of Lers Rors:
1) http://www.sfweekly.com/foodie/2011/10/05/qanda-with-lers-ross-chef-tom-silargorn-talking-about-real-thai-food
2) http://www.sfweekly.com/foodie/2011/10/05/qanda-with-lers-ross-tom-silargorn-part-2-about-that-new-restaurant
author: Amar P.

description: Had the chicken pad see ew and a thai iced tea - spent the rest of the evening in the hospital with the worst case of food poising. Perhaps they need to have safer food handling practices or check expiration dates better :(
author: Marisa L.

description:
Some coworkers and I came her for lunch and was quite impressed. $10 lunch special has good variety and some gluten free options in there, you just need to ask which ones. That said, surprisingly, all the curries were not gluten free (they add soy sauce). 

Good service, pretty knowledgable staff, fresh decor. I'd come back.
author: Vanessa C.

description: Really enjoyed the basic steamed chicken, rice, and soup dish,- can't remember the Thai name of it. What really stood out was the rice because they added a lot of white and black pepper into the rice (I am guessing) which made it flavorful on its own (maybe it was cooked in chicken broth too). It was simple and delicious comfort food! Also very nice of them to accommodate a large group with separate checks.
author: Regina C.

description: I used to come here because I enjoyed the Pad See Ew a lot. Then something happened - maybe they got a new chef or something. It was obscenely covered in white pepper - so much so that we couldn't not say something. They apologized and offered us a complimentary order next time we came back, which was ridiculously oily. Basically, you're better off at another Thai place in the area.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Okay and Overpriced; way overpriced!

Dinner dishes range from 13 to 21 dollars + rice. I had the red curry with duck and a glass of Pinot. Ended up paying 35 dollars. Tom Ka soup 10 bucks; really?

Whoever that design this place is a genius. The decor is superb. The device is good and atmosphere high end. The food; pretty much the same as Osha or Thai House 530; this last one being the best. 

Not coming back.
author: Moy V.

description:
In my opinion, it's difficult to find great Thai food in the Bay Area. My favorite is still Sala Thai in Fremont. But in SF, my favorite is Ler Ros in the Tenderloin. However, I hate the wait there for a casual last-minute dinner. So it's great to have the Ler Ros Mission location -- much easier to get into, nicer decor and cooler neighborhood. The TL location still seems to have tad better food, but isn't that always the case with hole-in-the-wall originals?

For a lot of your typical curries and Thai standbys, Ler Ros is pretty standard compared to other decent Thai restaurants. Where this place really stands out is in their speciality dishes like the crispy pork belly and duck larb. Read the TL restaurant Yelp reviews and order the dishes that most people rave about.
author: Michelle F.

description: Have eaten here a few times and have been happy with the food although they always seem to be rushing to get you in and out. Ordered takeout today and was very disappointed. Vegetables tasted like plastic or synthetic cooking spray and were inedible. Noodles and chicken were burnt and looked like left over scraps of stir fry chicken. Will not order again.
author: Jake K.

description: Today was my first time at the 16th Street location, and I had an excellent experience!  I had the lunch special - salad, rice, and two mains for $10.  I got the ginger chicken and eggplant/tofu as my mains, and both were delicious!  My fiancé liked his minced chicken and veggies with peanut sauce. The food came out quickly, and the service was friendly and efficient.  Definitely a great lunch spot in the Mish!
author: Barnali D.

description:
My local buddy recommended this place as a go to thai restaurant and it delivered. 

****get the pork shoulder app! The lime chili sauce compliments this succulent meat perfectly. ****

Everything here is cooked fresh and wonderful. I had the glass noodles with prawn  and my wife has the green curry. 

What best is the prices. While the quality demands recognition the prices make it approachable. Very moderately price for how good it is. Only reason why it got 4 stars is because my food was forgotten so i can't give them a 5 but when it arrived it was spectacular.
author: jackson h.

description:
If you're more of a chicken pad thai and satay kind of Thai food fan, you should probably scan down to some other reviews. However, if you're a fan of slightly more authentic thai food, maybe in the key of northern thai? You're in good hands. 
Ordered the Moo Phing (pork), which was quite tasty, as well as the Rad Nah (noodles in gravy) which is comfort food if I've ever had it. 

But the winner? The Nuer Pad Prik. Possibly some of the most delicious seasoned beef I've ever had. It's a few extra dollars compared to the noodles, but worth it. 

Main gripe though? Once they close? They *close*. Even 15 minutes after locking the doors, we were basically rushed out the door. If the food wasn't so delicious, I might have been more cranky about it.
author: Brett W.

description: I had the yellow curry and it was delicious. Service is good and fast, a little slow for the water refills.  I came for the lunch special, not on holidays. Be aware.
author: Francisco G.

description: Have been to this Lers Ros location many times, mostly because of the ambience rather than the food, which has always been just OK. Last night, I went there with some friends visiting and ordered the chicken pad kee mow. While eating it, I noticed the chicken was a bit funky, but pushed through and boy do I wish I hadn't. I've had awful food poisoning for the last 24 hours and based on the rest of my diet that day, I'm confident it was because of that meal. I won't be going back to Lers Ros anytime soon.
author: Elton D.

description:
Just stopped by at Lers Ros Thai #3 in Mission today for lunch.  Very very disappointed, the service was great but the food is worse  over-sweetened both red curry chicken and pork fried with black pepper and garlic, I thought I am eating dessert! I am Thai so I can tell the difference between a 
good red curry chicken and the not so good one.  I will stick with the original one in Tenderloin on Larkin Street. I am a regular at Larkin since 2008 the place was a hole-in-the-wall.  Now the place is look nicer but food is starting to go south.  Khun Tom & Khun Aoy you better taste 
your food before it is too late!!!I give overall - Lers Ros #1- 4star; #2 - 3star; #3 - 2star.
author: Don C.

description:
Very good authentic Thai food. We arrived late for our reservation (45 min) but it was no problem, they sat us very quickly in a very busy restaurant. 
  We had I had the curry shrimp with veggies and  noodles. The waitress said it wasn't to hot! It was fairly hot but extremely tasty. Another dish on our table was Pad Thai delightful came with lots of sprouts. On a side note the rabbit was tasty but had small bones, which we should have been informed about. It was extremely awkward to eat. The venison was simply amazing. We also had a bottle of French wine by Belaire it was a beautifully complex yet crisp Chardonnay. The restaurant was noisy and hopping. The service was awesome and on top of us!
 Great meals, good prices $12-$17 can't wait to go back again!
author: Megan M.

description: The portion is kinda big so I didn't have the chance to try many dishes haha. But the food is really good and their brown rice is yummy. Would love to go back to try more dishes, they have a wide variety of food there :D
author: Quynh Nga D.

description: This location is definitely the worst. I came here with my family for my mom's birthday. We were greeted by the host and got seated. The restaurant was not busy at all on a Wednesday night. The waiters were just standing around talking. Our waiter Toey was so RUDE. She had an attitude and rushed us to order. The food was mediocre. I've had better. Even King of Thai is better than this expensive place. Toey, our waiter came and took our plates without even asking us if we were finished. Seemed like she was trying to rush us out of there. She even handed us the bill right away. My brother wasn't done eating either. RUDE, I tell you. I asked for a side of sauce for our leftover chicken. She forgot 3 times! All she was doing was standing there chit chatting. Do your job. You have no customers
author: Stephanie L.

description: Wonderful Thai food and very nice atmosphere. I live in Phx, but am originally from Seattle where there is good food of all types. Thai food is a favorite of mine, however, and my selection just is not what it was up there. So when I was visiting San Fran I got some suggestions and ended up here! Not a disappointment at all. Great vegetarian options and they were very accommodating to changes in dishes.
author: Aleah S.

description: EEEUUUUU! Fruit flys, chewy, fatty beef.....I wont be going back here. I will say this...The service was GREAT and so was the Tom Kha Kai but....thats about it.
author: Toni T.

description: I love this place. Came here on a girls night out and it was fantastic. We came here on a Wednesday night and got seated right away. The staff was friendly and the decor was amazing. Modern Neo- Thai, loved it. We all started with Thai Ice Tea, and honestly I am not a big fan of Thai Ice Teas because they are normally way to sweet for me, but I really enjoyed the one I had. Also had a rose with it, so maybe that helped :). The food was excellent. I had the green curry with chicken and shrimp with sticky rice. The green curry was really delicious, and the coconut milk was just enough to make it sweet and spicy at the same time. I liked that the sticky rice came in a bamboo container, really good presentation. My friend had the beef Pad Se Ew and she said it was bomb. We also had the fried banana with vanilla ice cream drizzled with honey and it was so so good. We all agreed it was just the perfect spot for girls night. The ambience was great for catching up, the music wasn't too loud.
author: Faith C.

description: Ordered online through their system. One hour goes by, no food. Gave them a call and the lady said they see the order but it never got to the kitchen. Please fix your online delivery system. Complete waste of time.
author: Vaibhav S.

description:
the best Thai food I've ever had in my life and in such a nice atmosphere. 

papaya salad with raw blue crab. who serves raw crab? they do and it will melt in your mouth. be aware that this papaya salad is also the spiciest Thai salad you'll ever eat because that's really how it's supposed to be prepared.

the best Tom Kha soup - chicken and coconut tamarind served in a boiling hot pot. so much lemongrass, galangal and red chilis. 

grilled pork shoulder. speechless. one of my favorite cuts of meat done so well. 

they also have rabbit, venison, alligator and a ton of different types of fish. the entire restaurant smelled of fish sauce and shrimp paste - my kind of smell lol. 

no one spoke when eating because it was that good. also, i was busy taking gulps of water because my mouth was burning the entire time. so worth the burn though.
author: Thao T.

description:
Over priced, with ever shrinking portions. Chicken and vegetables, with little
Of either. Thai shouldn't cost $60 for two dishes and noodle dish. Time to move on!
author: M G.

description: I really wanted to like this place, but after ordering takeout twice and having it be inedibly salty - like horribly grossly salty- I won't be going back. :(
author: Macheeks ..

description: Great place..Great food..loved the red curry and the green curry..very welcoming and polite hostess..overall a good experience!!!
author: Umang M.

description: Cool environment. I wasn't treated very nice when I told them they gave me the wrong order.  They did fix it though but it Wasatch hassle.
author: Niya S.

description:
Ate here for dinner last night and it was quite possibly the worst meal I've had yet in San Francisco. We were seated right away, though it was quite full since it was a Saturday evening at prime time. I can't fathom why so many people were there, and even more, looking happy!

_ decor kind of sucks. It looks like they tried, but were unsuccessful - uncomfortable Bertoia/Eames-inspired wire mesh chairs, seats and tables that aren't appropriately scaled to each other, weird ceiling mesh, orange wall paint, terrible acoustics, etc.
_ the noise! Holy crap I have a sore throat from the yelling I had to do just to converse with my single dining partner. Not sure how you could come here with a group of people and ever be heard.
_ the food was not good, at all. We started with the papaya salad with salted egg and it was so salty we couldn't even finish the dish (and we have *very* high tolerances for both salt and egg). Followed that with pad thai that was simultaneously too acidic and syrupy sweet and, again, not finishable. The pad kee mao was also too sweet and the tofu tasted like the pre-packed kind that is fried in industrial vats of oil, not like something they are actually cooking themselves.
_ the service was not good. They forgot one of our dishes and we had to flag down a server to ask where it was, then watch her go through the motions of discovering that it somehow got lost in the shuffle. We had already eaten an appetizer and split the nasty Pad Thai at that point, and instead of owning up to the mistake and asking if we still wanted the dish, they squeezed it into the kitchen line up and brought out a dish that was too hot to eat a few minutes later.
_ the tables are set very strangely - with both a placemat and a "charger" that are present throughout the meal. They bring a smaller plate for the appetizer and place that over the "charger," which of course guarantees that the charger gets sauce and bits of food on it. The server additionally spilled food all over my boyfriend's "charger" as he took away the appetizer, which led to another server a few minutes later trying to take away my "charger," before realizing we haven't had our food yet. In short, the "charger" is actually a dinner plate, but by the time I get to eat off of it, it has food, saucer, and fingerprints all over it. Fantastic.
_ Finishing touches: no apology for the food mix up, resulting in a $20+ dinner/person that was grossly not worth that; a restaurant that seemed fully staffed and yet we were waiting significant amounts of time between each course; so much chaos! Again, I don't understand why someone would subject themselves to that much chaotic energy in one restaurant. Dining should be enjoyable, not a shit show.
author: Megan S.

description: I've been to their Tenderloin restaurant a number of times and I happened to walk past this one. I gave it a try and the food is just as good as the other one. Highly recommend anyone looking for good Thai food.
author: John D.

description: Love this place. So glad for the Mission branch. I asked the waiter to recommend something and he steered me to the tendon noodle soup which is by far the best I've had in SF.
author: Steven W.

description: I really wanted to like this place.  Ordered everything that was popular on yelp.  Papaya salad, pork belly, pad Se ew and duck larb.  The only thing that was good was the pad Se ew but really just reminded me of greasy chow fun. The papaya salad tasted like I was eating lettuce soaked in perfume.  Wayy too strong in flavor.  Pork belly Was crispy but lacked any kind of flavoring and duck larb was completely forgettable.  Their fried quail wings were a good app and got my hopes up in thinking the rest of the food would be just as good.  Wine didn't pair with any food ordered and just didn't taste good by itself.  Will not be returning ever.
author: Jennifer G.

description: My favorite thai place in the city. Service is spotty but worth it. The vegetarian green curry is amazing. The pad see ew is awesome. Make a reservation and go.
author: S Y.

description: This place does Thai food right. Our server was great. A girlfriend and I scarfed down everything. We had the Tom Yum Koong with shrimp, green curry with chicken, and Pad Thai. This is one of the best Thai restaurants I've been to. The food is flavorful. I've been to a few where the food is bland or the Pad Thai tastes drenched in ketchup....ew. I would definitely come back here if I'm back in SF and craving Thai food.
author: Ashley H.

description: I love their curries and pad see ew. Their food is better then the Thai place that was there before. My go to place for Thai in my neighborhood.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Great new addition to Mission neighborhood  dining. The most authentic Thai food I've had in San Francisco. And the 16th & Guerrero location is a vast improvement on their Tenderloin location. The inside is inviting and nicely laid out. We had the fried vegetable rolls to start. I had the Kang Kareem, a yellow curry that I asked for chicken. The other main was Pad Thai. The flavors were closer to those of Bangkok than any other place I've been to in San Fran. Only caveat is ask for mild unless you truly can take VERY hot food. Mild was ok for me, mediums was a bit too hot for either of us and my dining partner has an asbestos mouth. The service was fast and efficient. We arrived at 9:45 on a Thursday (July 3rd nite) 15 minutes before closing but were served before 10. Want to go back and try more from the extensive menu. Appetizers from $8-10 and mains $10-15.
author: Armando H.

description:
Heard about this place from a co-worker and decided to take wife for dinner while we were in the city last night. Parking was horrible, as always, but that didn't stop up from trying, which now I know should have...
Decor is trendy and staff seems friendly, and that's all I can say about this place. 
We've ordered two of their special dishes, cod and alligator, two glasses of wine and brown rice, all on the menu. One thing we've asked to be made off the menu was green beans with garlic sauce, instead of their spicy-as-hell red sauce, for which we were charged 10.95 and beans were old as hell, but that wasn't the worst. The fish and alligator were so gawd-damn-salty, it was just impossible to eat. At some point my wife made a comment "honey, would you like some food with your salt?" I mean holly shit, salt and red spicy sauce were the main dishes and had some fish and alligator on a side. And now I know why...fast forward 3 hours, and I've got the shits! I was singing and praying to Lord to help pass that food out of my body in non-violent matter as much as possible, and thanking my lucky stars that it happened at home. In order to mask the "freshness" of their ingredients, they use the salt and pepper very generously. 
Because of those effers, I had to have milanta and emmodium for desert, instead of "sexy-time" with my wife. Screw you bustards! I'm never coming back to your place! and I'm going back to work on Monday to find my co-worker and beating the crap out of him for recommending this place...
TWO stars is me being generous, and a rating for a decor and staff, food rating is...crap!
author: Abe L.

description: Pricey but delicious and pretty legit flavor and spice wise.
author: Alex S.

description: Sticky rice with mango was perfect!  Portion size was good too.
author: Heather C.

description: Great service, amazing authentic and tasty food, and love the decor.  Most of the food is cooked in medium spice so be prepared if you are not used to a little zip.  Overall great food and amazing service.
author: Mookey G.

description:
Maybe this will be the first installment of my new series, "Low Quality Lifestyles in the San Francisco Bay Area". 

I had the pork and black mushroom dish. The dish would be more aptly named: "Pork and Onions". 

The description on the menu did not indicate onions nor carrots however those vegetables dominated the dish. And salt. The onion taste was over-powering. The pork was sparse and pathetic little pieces and overly salty; some with gristle varying from not pleasant to inedible. I did not bother counting the black mushrooms because it was hard not to notice the two pieces; who counts to two? There must have been at least $1.17 worth of food product in my $11 entree. 

If a salty taste equates to flavor, then the dish provided an overly flavorful experience dominated with fresh white onion vapor in my sinuses. 

Special thanks to Lers Ros management for giving me that totally ripped off feeling.
author: Keith U.

description: I am not the hugest Thai fan , but every blue moon I get a yen to explore it. I saw this had opened on my walk through my neighborhood today and stopped in to get some takeout . I ordered their noodle soup with beef and meatballs , and their version of chicken curry samosas. The soup was good , not overly sodiumy . You get to pick what kind of noodle you want. The samosas were ok. This place is clean and nice, maybe I will decide to try here again and get more adventurous with my ordering .Nice addition to the neighborhood
author: Lauren V.

description: Really liked this place. One of the best thai food in SF with a lot of interesting ingredients. It's not hard to book so perfect for big group of people.
author: George L.

description: I've had delicious food twice at this newer location.   Tod mun fish cakes excellent, duck curry excellent, blackfish special excellent.
author: Michael H.

description: HORRIBLE. I love this place but I waited an hour and thirty minutes for a delivery that should've taken 45 minutes to find that the driver just went back to the restaurant because apparently he came to my house, rang the doorbell (no doorbell ring), and phone call (phone was dead charging). I was waiting for a doorbell ring per usual which never happened I've been chillin and netflixin in the room right next to the front door this whole time and now they won't deliver my food because they're closed. IM HANGRY AF AND NOW IT'S TOO LATE TO ORDER ELSEWHERE. EFFING DISGRACE.
author: Hana G.

description: mmmm!  the laarb gai, noodle soups and minced port are excellent. Some of the best Thai I've had in SF, reminded me of the food we used to eat in Bangkok.  Love the location, place needs sound proofing as it is very loud.  The best times for a meal are before or after dinner/ lunch crowds, as it is a better dining experience.
author: Aque R.

description: Solid basic thai fare. We went here on a glowing recommendation so maybe our expectations were too high. Super attentive service and great window dining. Yum!
author: James S.

description: Place is little pricey for the taste of the food. Curry needed little more coconut for my taste. Papaya salad is alright though.
author: Vince M.

description: This is a mediocre Thai restaurant. The atmosphere of the restaurant is nice and trendy but the food lacks flavor and substance. Prices a little high for Thai. The service is fine but not engaging. The music in the restaurant was dance pop which is silly for a Thai restaurant. This place is trying to hard to be something they are not. The table for 2 is too small if you are ordering more than 2 dishes. If you want thai in a nice setting this could be for you.
author: Zee R.

description: Yum!  have only visited twice but plan to keep coming back to try more from the menu.  For both visits we were there late afternoon (before 5pm) which at this location  means there's plenty of tables and attentive service.  While I'm no expert on thai cuisine, the menu here is a little less conventional than many other thai restaurants, which I also like.  Can't wait to return!
author: Annie P.

description: Favorite Thai restaurant in SF! Solid, consistant good food and great service.  Both the Mission and Hayes Valley locations exude great atmosphere without being pretentious.
author: Nicole Q.

description:
LOVE this place. I spent some time in Thailand after college and haven't had Thai food this good since.  The food at Lers Ros is authentic, superrr tasty and it has a very fun ambiance. 

We went there on a Thursday night and were seated right away (we had a reservation). The waiters were really friendly and helped us navigate the extensive menu. Also loved their drinks menu, especially their variety of Thai beers... felt like being back in Thailand. We ordered a chicken coconut milk curry and the pad see-ew and it was *amazing*. Would definitely recommend to anyone. For dessert, we had the mango sticky rice and it tasted right :) 

They also had really fun music playing in the background that gave the place a loungy-vibe. Will be coming back here a lot!
author: Ana M.

description: Average food. The Pad Thai is sickeningly sweet. Service was average. The decor is nice. Finding good Thai food in San Francisco is a real challenge. We had hope for Lers Ros. It's hard to taste the food with all the sugar added to the sauces. Keep looking, there's nothing here to see (or taste)
author: Dennver C.

description: After coming to this location a couple of times, and frequenting the one in the TL for over 5 years, I have to say that the food is taking a turn, which really bums me out. I loved this place so much and I am disappointed in the recent change in food quality - to the point that I am writing my first review after being a yelp consulter for years. I hope the other locations are maintaining the same level of quality that they had before this one opened. I now understand why they have a lesser rating. Bummed.
author: erin l.

description: Delicious! My boyfriend and I went here and just asked our server for recommendations when we ordered. We has really tasty stir fried tofu with ginger and spicy prawns with peppers. The service was really fast and the food was delightful. The prawns were really tender and moderately spicy, and the tofu was really flavorful, especially given that it was cooked in a pretty mildly flavored sauce. I'd recommend making reservations if you can, though- we ended up waiting almost 20 minutes on a Sunday night.
author: Sharmin K.

description: We actually had this ridiculous table on the left at the entrance, basically you're looking at the people coming in like a receptionist. It's so ridiculous cheap to actually squeeze a table in to that spot. Anyway, the food did not make up for it either, it's slightly pricier than other Thai places including several right next door, and it's much worse. I actually don't even remember what we had, which probably means something. It's just boring. The styling of the restaurant is pretty good though but primarily I am looking for good food, and that's not it. Ah I remember, the rabbit (fried bones you can try to chew on) was it.
author: Hendrik G.

description: Love the food here.  The coconut soup and the duck larb were delicious.  The service could be improved.  Workers texting on their cell phones and having conversations with each other in the back.  Never checked if I needed anything.  Finally, got someone's attention to get some water.  We was there late so not very busy. The service is better at the Hayes St. location.  Have not been to the Larkin location.
author: Nora S.

description: Best Thai in SF! Excellent Service and nice atmosphere. The servers are always very attentive. It really is never a disappointment. I'm here at least once a week, realistically.
author: Juan T.

description: Stumbled on this place in the Tenderloin. The outside looks like any Thai restaurant in the TL/Nob Hill, and the inside is decorated very simply. The food is the highlight and its distinguishing factor. The vegetables in the dishes we ordered were perfectly spiced and with minimal oil. The flavors were therefore very distinct and differentiated. The presentation of the dishes was above average and the service accompanying the food was very pleasant. The only downside of the restaurant was a strong salty fishy smell, but this was a minor negative. I would recommend the broccoli in bean paste if you're looking for a light but tasty meal.
author: Nikhil V.

description: Tom Kha tastes the way tom kha is supposed to taste. sour and sweet and spicy!
author: lauren h.

description: We went for dinner there last week to try something new. The service was mediocre, the music too loud and didn't really fit a Thai place. My boyfriends soup was great, my vegetarian sweet/sour dish was pretty bad. I think I could have cooked it better myself. Way too much fish sauce. Would not go again.
author: Anna W.

description: Phenomenal thai food. My favorite cuisine, having had it all over Thailand, I can confidently say this place comes very close. Ranked highly so I'm told, deservedly so. Thai soup was amazing, as were the shrimp and beef dishes we ordered.
author: Hissam A.

description: This is the second time we've eaten at Lers Ros. We have dined at their original Mission Street restaurant and tried their new Mission location last night. This review is really intended to give the Lers Ros mgmt some feedback on the dining experience that may be of benefit. My wife, youngest son (11) and I had dinner at Lers Ros last night in the Mission. The food was excellent and the service was great! So...why only two stars? The noise level was deafening and overwhelming and literally ruined our dinner. We did not have this same experience when we dined at the Tenderloin location back in October 2013. We enjoy a lively, happening atmosphere as much as the next person, but the noise was so bad from the surrounding tables, it literally impacted the enjoyment of our meal, and we all agreed that it wouldn't be a place we'd go again (unless improvements were made). The space is smaller than the Tenderloin location so perhaps that contributed to it? Noise acoustics are something that the ownership/mgmt can do something about, so I am writing this review in that spirit. You can still have a great ambience, but put in some acoustic elements to bring down the oppressive sound. Hope to see Lers Ros make these changes as it would be bummer to have to strike some of the best Thai food in the City as an option.
author: Lawson C.
